projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Arcana Clericalia, Or, THE MYSTERIES OF Clark≈øhip: BEING A ≈øure way of Setling E≈øtates By DEEDS, FINES, and RECOVERIES. With the Forms of all manner of Charter-Parties in Maritime Cities, Towns and Corporations. WITH A TABLE of all the Principal matters therein contained. By George Billinghur≈øt of Grayes-Inne E≈øq;

div.head: TO THE Practitioners and Students OF THE Common LAW OF ENGLAND: E≈øpecially ≈øuch as would be throughly Acquainted with Conveyancing.
div.p: WIthout the lea≈øt Flattery to the Memory of our decea≈øed Author, I may boldly ≈øay, His indefatigable Labours need not be u≈øher'd into the World with ≈øtudied Eulogyes: And I doubt not but you will concur with me in the ≈øame Opinion, when you have perus'd this Book, and confe≈øs his own Labours to be his greate≈øt Commendation.

Touching the Subject matter, it contains the ≈øeveral Forms of Settlements of E≈øtates to U≈øes, with power for Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe for Life, and in Tayl, to make Joyntures, Lea≈øes, and, Grants of Rents: Likewi≈øe the Forms of Limitation of U≈øes for Years; for payment of Debts, di≈øcharge of Sureties, and rai≈øing of Portions for Younger Children: It al≈øo treats of Limitation of U≈øes in Fee, for the Lands to be ≈øold to pay Debts, &c. With ≈øeveral forms of Revocation of U≈øes, and limiting ∆≤≈øes de novo, and of Covenants, with other Incidents to the like Conveyances.

Be≈øides the≈øe, there are other mo≈øt u≈øeful Pre≈øidents, relating to Merchants and Traders Affairs, fit for all Maritime Cities, Towns, and places of Trade: The whole Work is ≈øo Methodically dige≈øted
by the Author, that any Per≈øon (who is not a meer stranger to the Law) may make great u≈øe and advantage thereof, and ≈øpeedily and readily find any particular matter therein contained.

As to the Author, I ≈øhall only ≈øay thus much in general of him, viz. That H ‚Ä¢ ≈øpent a con≈øiderable time in the ≈øtudy of the Law at Grays-Inne, and being unwearied in ≈øearching after all opportunities to improve his knowledge, He at length was call'd to the Barr, and gain'd in a little time the Vogue of being a profound and judicious Coun≈øellor; His Apprehen≈øion was alwaies quick, his Judgment deliberate, ≈øolid, and not wavering, of a clear di≈øcerning faculty, his Memory ≈øound, and his Patience (the truest index of a Wi≈øe man) alwaies commanded his Pa≈ø≈øions: in ≈øhort, He was a Per≈øon of exqui≈øite, natural, and acquired
Parts, and that which much contributed to the latter, was his great Moderation and Temperance, whereby his study and bu≈øine≈øs glided in their delighted Channels, uninterrupted. Being at length wearied with Bu≈øine≈øs, he retir'd into the Country, where having fini≈øh'd this Elaborate Work, he dyed. Since who≈øe death, his Manu≈øcript being left to the Guardian≈øhip of a Friend, and committed into my hands, in order to be made Publick, for the further advantage of ≈øuch as would be perfect in the ≈øetling of E≈øtates. I have hereunto added the Learning touching Fines and Recoveries, hoping the Ingenious will be moderate in their Cen≈øures; And if I have, in this, done any thing to your Advantage, it will an≈øwer the pains of him that is,

div.head: Arcana Clericalia: OR, The My≈øteries of Clerk≈øhip: Containing the Forms of Settlement of E≈øtates to u≈øes; with power to make Joyntures, Lea≈øes, Grants, &c.
The Fir≈øt Part.
CHAP. I. Some Ob≈øervations taken out of our late Reports, and Books touching the Law of Conveyances in general.
div.p: 1. A Bargains and ≈øells to B. a MannorFine joyned, with other a≈ø≈øurances extingui≈øheth not a condition. &c. and Covenants to ≈øuffer a Recovery; and levie a Fine for better a≈ø≈øurance of the Mannor: and that all E≈øtates, a≈ø≈øurances and conveyances after to be made of the ≈øaid Mannor, ≈øhould be to the u≈øes in the ≈øaid Indenture &c. And in the ≈øaid Indenture there is a Provi≈øo that B. (the Bargainee) ≈øhall do ≈øuch an Act, &c. And it was re≈øolved that this Provi≈øo amounts to a condition in Law to defeat the whole E≈øtate: and although A. and B. after levied a Fine to a third Per≈øon, in reference to the Covenant afore≈øaid, yet it was re≈øolved, that the Fine did not extingui≈øh the ≈øaid condition, for it was as an a≈ø≈øurance, and was to be guided by the Indenture: Cook lib. 2. 72, 73. Lord Cromwels ca≈øe. vide Dyer 157. pag. 28, 29, 30.

2. Al≈øo it was re≈øolved in the ≈øaid Cromwells ca≈øe, Several conveyances, &c. do make but one a≈ø≈øurance in Law. fo. 75. a. that the ≈øaid bargain and ≈øale, and Recoverie, and Fine, although made, ≈øuffered and levied at ≈øeveral times, do make but one a≈ø≈øurance in Law of the Mannor, according to the ≈øame original bargain and contract; and every of them tend to perfect the ≈øaid Bargain and Sale, and none of them to de≈øtroy any part of it, or to ≈øubvert the true intent of the Parties: As, if a man makes a Lea≈øe for life of Lands in ≈øeveral Counties, and fir≈øt makes livery in one County, and divers daies after maketh livery in another County; yet the Rent re≈øerved upon the
Lea≈øe ≈øhall i≈ø≈øue out of the Lands in both Counties, although the livery by which the e≈øtate pa≈ø≈øed, was made at ≈øeveral times: And therefore it might be objected, that pre≈øently upon the fir≈øt livery the Rent ≈øhould i≈ø≈øue out of it: but the Law ≈øhall not judge by parcels in ≈øubverting of the intent and agreement of the Parties, but after all the Acts are done, in performance of the original contract and agreement of the Parties, the Law ≈øhall adjudge upon all, as executed at the ≈øame time. So if one make a deed of Feoffment, with warranty, and deliver the deed to the Feoffee, and after at another time maketh livery, ≈øecundum formam Charta, yet the warranty is good, although when the deed was delivered, no e≈øtate pa≈ø≈øed, to which the warranty might be annexed: yet notwith≈øtanding, praxis juris p ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øtorum is to be ob≈øerved, Et qui rationem in omnibus quarunt, ra ‚Ä¢ ionem ≈øubvertunt: Cook l. 2. 75. a. Conveyances to be ≈øo con≈øtrued that they may take effect.

3. A Conveyance ≈øhall have ≈øuch con≈øtruction that it may take effect: ut res magis valeat qu√†m pereat. If Tenant for life, and he in Remainder or Rever≈øion, joyn in a Feoffment by deed; each one of them pa≈ø≈øeth his e≈øtate, (viz.) the Le≈ø≈øee for life his e≈øtate by the livery, and the Fee-≈øimple moveth or pa≈ø≈øeth from him in Remainder or Rever≈øion: but if the Feoffment had been by Paroll, then it ≈øhould have been the Feoffment of him in Remainder or Rever≈øion, and a ≈øurrender of the Le≈ø≈øee for life, for otherwi≈øe nothing ≈øhould pa≈øs by Paroll. Cook lib. 2.Fine, works to corroborate a former e≈øtates and makes no di≈øcontinuance. fol. 15.

4. Tenent in Tail by deed inrolled, bargains and ≈øells an hou≈øe to another and his heirs: and after the Tenant in Tail levies a Fine with Proclamations to the Bargainee of the ≈øame hou≈øe: Re≈øolved, 1. That by the Indenture of bargain and ≈øale inrolled, the Bargainee had an E≈øtate de≈øcendible to his heirs, but it was determinable by the death of the Tenant in Tail. 2. Re≈øolved, that the Fine here levied to the Bargainee doth not make a Di≈øcontinuance of the Remainder in Tail, nor doth any E≈øtate of Free-hold pa≈øs by the Fine: but only the Fine with
the Proclamations doth corroborate the E≈øtate of the Bargainee, and the Stat. of 4 H. 7, chap. 24. and 32 H. 8. cap. 36. makes his E≈øtate more perdurable, being (after the Fine) determinable only upon the death of Tenant in Tail without i≈ø≈øue; but if the Fine had been levied before the bargain and ≈øale inrolled, it had been a di≈øcontinuance; but in the ca≈øe before it was not, becau≈øe it operated only upon the E≈øtate which pa≈ø≈øed precedent. Cook lib. 10. fol. 96. Edward Seymors ca≈øe.

5. Nota a diver≈øity when a man hath two wayesTwo waies to pa≈øs an E≈øtate ho ‚Ä¢ taken‚ñ™ to pa≈øs Lands, and both of them by the Commonlaw, and intends to pa≈øs them by one of tho≈øe wayes: yet, ut res magi ‚Ä¢ valcat, it ≈øhall pa≈øs by the other. As if a man be ≈øeized of two Acres of Land in Fee, and lettath one of them for Years, and makes a Charter of Feoffment of both, and maketh livery only of the Acre in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, in the name of both, only the. Acre in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion pa≈ø≈øeth: but if the le≈ø≈øee for years after doth attorne, then both ≈øhall pa≈øs: becau≈øe he is by the common Law in the Per as to both: but, when a man may pa≈øs Lands either by the common Law, or by rai≈øing of a u≈øe and ≈øetling of it by the Statute, there in many ca≈øes it is otherwi≈øe: As, if the Father makes a Charter of Feoffment to the Son, and a let ‚Ä¢ er of Attorney to make livery; if no livery be made, no u≈øe ≈øhall ari≈øe unto the Son, becau≈øe then he ≈øhould be in by the Statute in another degree, (viz.) in the Po≈øt: and the intention of the Parties is much in the rai≈øing of u≈øes. Cook upon Lit. 49. a.

6. One ≈øells unto another certain Lands byActs done for further a≈ø≈øurance referre to the Original agreement. deed indented, upon condition of Reentry, upon nonpayment of 20 l. and that all a≈ø≈øurances ≈øhall then be to him and his heirs: and Covenants to make other a≈ø≈øurances, and that they ≈øhall be to the u≈øe in the Indenture: afterwards he makes a Feoffment to the ≈øame bargainee, to the u≈øe of him and his heirs, and afterwards levies a Fine to him, which was to the u≈øes in the Indenture: and it was judged, that notwith≈øtanding this ab≈øolute Feoffment, and to an expre≈øs u≈øe; yet it being made upon no new agreement, it
≈øhall be guided by the Covenant, ≈øo that the bargainees E≈øtate continues conditional. Crook lib. 1. fol. 300. pag. 14. Clever ver≈ø. Giles. Acts done for further a≈ø≈øurance upon covenants precedent, conteined in the original agreement, ≈øhall have ≈øuch con≈øtruction as may fortify and not de≈øtroy the fir≈øt agreement. As if ‚Ä¢ man bargain and ≈øell Lands rendring rent, with condition of reentrie &c. and covenants to make further a≈ø≈øurances; and after he levies a Fine, or makes a Feoffment: none of the≈øe are con≈øtrued to extingui≈øh the rent, or condition, but to fortify only the E≈øtate of the purcha≈øer according to the fir≈øt agreement. Moores Reports fol. 385.

7. It ≈øeems a conveyance of record ≈øhall be
‚Ä¢ nv eyan ‚Ä¢ e of record and enpays, how taken. taken ≈øtrictly and not by intendment: as a conveyance in pais ≈øhall. Therefore a Mannor in reputation, which is not a Mannor in truth, will not pa≈øs by the name of a Mannor, in a Fine or common Recovery: otherwi≈øe in a conveyance. Crook part 1. 524. p. 53. yet a remainder may pa≈øs in a Fine by the name of a Rever≈øion, ibid. 594. p. 37.

8. Where an Indenture of bargain and ≈øale isSeveral conveyances: how the Party ≈øhall be in. made, and after a Fine is levied of the ≈øame land to the bargainee, and after the deed is inrolled, the bargainee is in by the Fine, and not by the inrollment: and where a Rever≈øion is bargained and ≈øold by Indenture, and before inrolment, a Fine is levyed by the Bargainor to the Bargainee, and after the deed is inrolled, yet the Bargainee mu≈øt have an Attornment, becau≈øe he is in by the Fine and not by the Bargain and ≈øale. Crook part 1. 917. p. 8.

9. Where it is po≈ø≈øible for a grant to take effectGrant to take effect as by po≈øsibility it may. according to the Letter, there the Law makes ≈øuch a con≈øtruction, as by po≈øsibility it may take effect: as if Lands are given to two men, and the Heirs of their two Bodies, the Law makes them joynt-tenants for life, and gives them ≈øeveral Inheritances in Tail. Cook upon Litt. 183. b. Stamford ju≈øticeThree grounds for con≈øtruction of deeds. (arguendo) taketh three grounds for the con≈øtruction of deeds, Fir≈øt, that it ≈øhall be taken mo≈øt beneficially for the Party that taketh by them. Secondly, that the deed ≈øhall not be void, where
the words may be taken to any intent. Thirdly, that the words ≈øhall be con≈øtrued according to the mind of the parties and not otherwi≈øe: Plowden, Antient deeds how con≈øtrued. fol. 160. Throgmortons ca≈øe. Antient deeds ≈øhall be con≈øtrued, as they were antiently taken, although the Law be ≈øince altered: vide Crook part 1. 633. p. 29.

10. Some words are large and have a general extent,Expo≈øition des parol ‚Ä¢ . and ≈øome have a proper and particular application: the former ≈øort may contain the latter, as dedi, or conce≈ø≈øi, may amount to a Grant, a Feoffment, a Gift, a Lea≈øe, a Relea≈øe, a Confirmation, or Surrender &c. and it is in the Election of the Party to u≈øe them, to which of the≈øe purpo≈øes he will ‚Ä¢ ; but a Relea≈øe, Confirmation, or Surrender &c. cannot amount to a Grant &c. nor a Surrender ‚Ä¢ a Confirmation, or to a Relea≈øe &c. becau≈øe they are proper and peculiar manner of conveyances, and are de≈øtined to a ≈øpecial end. Cook ≈øur Litt. 301. b.

div.p: 1. Witne≈ø≈øeth that the ≈øaid A. div.head: CHAP. III. Containing ≈øeveral Covenants.
div.p:
1. This Indenture &c. between A. B. and E.
To levie a Fine Sur cogniz. de droit come ceo. Per. Baron & feme. his Wife on the one part, and C. D. and G. I. CHAP. Containing ≈øeveral Forms, of Charter Parties, viz.

III. Chap. Containing ≈øeveral Forms of Co-Partner-Ships, and Covenants incident thereunto.
The Form of a Co-Partner-Ship, relating to Tran≈øactions, as well forreign as dome≈øtick Sect. 1, &c.

IV. Chap. Containing ≈øeveral Forms of In≈øtruments u≈øed between Merchants and Traders, at and after the di≈ø≈øolution of Co-Partner-≈øhip.

V. Chap. Containing ≈øome Pre≈øidents, relating to other matters between Traders.

D. his executors, admini≈øtrators or a≈ø≈øigns, upon the Non-performance, or Non-ob≈øervance of any of the ≈øaid Covenants and agreements, on his part to be done and performed according to the intent and true meaning of the≈øe pre≈øents.
The like for the other Partie, who is to bind him≈øelf, his Executors and Admini≈øtrators, and his Goods and Chattels in the like penalty of One thou≈øand pound to performe, &c.

div.head: Another, where the Ship is let for twelve Months, and the hire to be at a certain Sum by the Month.

Part-Owners of the good Ship called the D. of London, of the burthen of 200 Tuns or thereabouts, now riding at Anchor, in the River of Thames, within the Port of the City of London, of which ≈øhip the ≈øaid E. di≈øcord or contention to happen, grow or be moved, by and between the ≈øaid Parties or any of them, or the Executors or Admini≈øtrators of them or any of them, for, upon or by rea≈øon of the ≈øaid Trade, and joynt occupying, or any matter or thing thereupon depending, or upon or by rea≈øon of any matter or thing in the≈øe pre≈øents contained or expre≈ø≈øed, That then and ≈øo often from time to time as the ≈øame ≈øhall happen, and before any ≈øuit, arre≈øt or trouble, ≈øhall be attempted or begun by them or any of them, again≈øt the other, All and every the ≈øaid variances, differences, ≈øtrifes, doubts, controver≈øies and contentions, ≈øhall from time to time be referred and ≈øubmitted to the hearing, order, award and determination of four hone≈øt Per≈øons, being of the Company of Merchant-adventurers of England for the time being, whereof one ≈øhall be cho≈øen by the ≈øaid A. B. his Executors or Admini≈øtrators, one other by, &c. [naming the re≈øt] as Arbitrators, in and for all and every the premi≈ø≈øes, if they ≈øhall be content to undertake the variances, ≈øtrifes and contentions ≈øo to them to be referred within the ≈øpace of one month next after ≈øuch reference and ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to them made: And further, that they the ≈øaid A. B. C. D. E. F. and G. H. and every of them, their and every of their Executors and Admini≈øtrators re≈øpectively, for their ≈øeveral and particular parts, ≈øhall and will from time to time ≈øtand to‚ñ™ abide, obey, perform, fulfil and keep all and every ≈øuch end and ends, determination and judgment, as by the ≈øaid four Per≈øons ≈øo, as afore≈øaid, to be cho≈øen, ≈øhall from time to time be had, made and given in writing, for and in behalf of the ≈øaid Parties, as touching any the variances or differences afore≈øaid.

div.head: Another form of Copartner≈øhip between two Sale≈ø-men, as to matters here in England only.
div.p:
(67.) THis Indenture made, &c. Between A. B. of the one part, and C. D. of the other part: whereas the ≈øaid A. B. is p ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øe≈øt by Lea≈ø ‚Ä¢

B. And whereas the ≈øaid Parties are agreed to be Copartners in the An or Trade of a Sale≈øman, and in buying and ≈øelling of Apparel, and other things belonging to the ≈øaid Trade.

(68.) Now witne≈ø≈øeth the≈øe pre≈øents, thatBy way of Covenant. the ≈øaid A. B. for him≈øelf, his Executors, Admini≈øtrators and A≈ø≈øigns, doth Covenant, promi≈øe, grant and agree to and with the ≈øaid C. D. ≈øhall have, hold and enjoy the ≈øeveral Rooms hereafter mentioned, being part and parcel of the ≈øaid Me≈ø≈øuage: That is to ≈øay, &c. [naming the Rooms] And al≈øo free liberty of ingre≈øs, egre≈øs and regre≈øs to and from the ≈øaid Rooms, and premi≈ø≈øes, at all convenient and ≈øea≈øonable times, for the term of three years, commencing from the Fea≈øt day of St. Michael Th'archangel next enli ‚Ä¢ ing the Date of the≈øe pre≈øents: yeilding and paying therefore yearly unto the ≈øaid A. B. his Executors, Admini≈øtrators and A≈ø≈øigns, the yearly ≈øum of Ten pound of lawful Moneys of England, at four u≈øual Fea≈øts or terms in the year, that is to ≈øay, &c. by even and equal portions. And the ≈øaid C. D. for him≈øelf, his Executors and Admini≈øtrators,
doth Covenant and grant to and withLiberty to view the reparations. the ≈øaid A. B. his Executors and Admini≈øtrators by the≈øe pre≈øents, That he the ≈øaid C. D. ≈øhall and will from time to time, during the ≈øaid term, permit and ≈øuffer the ≈øaid A. B. and all tho≈øe of whom he holdeth the ≈øaid Me≈ø≈øuage, their Heirs, Executors and A≈ø≈øigns, and their workmen to enter, and come into and upon the ≈øeveral Rooms afore≈øaid, to view, ≈øearch and ≈øee the e≈øtate of the ≈øame.

(69). And this Indenture further witne≈ø≈øeth,Covenant to be Copartners for three years. That the ≈øaid A. B. and C. D. for the good liking and opinion, and ≈øpecial tru≈øt and confidence which each of them hath and repo≈øeth of, and in the other of them, and for the advanceing of their E≈øtate, are contented and agreed, and do by the≈øe pre≈øents Covenant, grant and agree, each of them to and with the other of them, his Executors and Admini≈øtrators, that they the ≈øaid Parties ≈øhall be and continue Copartners together, and joynt dealers in the Art or Mi≈øtery of a Sale≈øman, and the making and ≈øelling of all ≈øorts of Apparel for Men and Women, and in the buying and ≈øelling of all things thereunto incident and belonging, from the Fea≈øt day of Saint Michael Th'archangel, next en≈øuing the Date of the≈øe pre≈øents unto the end and term of three years, from thence next en≈øuing, and fully to be compleat and ended (if the ≈øaid Parties ≈øhall both of them ≈øo long live:) the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip to be kept and u≈øed in the Shop and Ware-hou≈øe belonging to the above-named Me≈ø≈øuage.

(70.) And for the better managing of the ≈øaidThe Stock to be brought in by each. joynt Trade, they the ≈øaid Parties to the≈øe pre≈øents, have agreed to make up, bring in, and put together the ≈øum of Four hundred pounds of lawful Moneys of England: of which ≈øaid Stock, the ≈øaid A. B. is agreed for his ≈øhare and part, to bring in the ≈øum of Two hundred pounds of lawful Moneys of England; and the ≈øaid C. D. is agreed to bring into the ≈øaid Stock for his
part and ≈øhare of the ≈øaid joynt Stock, the like ≈øum of Two hundred pounds of like lawful Moneys of England, being the re≈øidue of the ≈øaid Four hundred pounds, and they the ≈øaid Parties ≈øhall and may bring, and put into the ≈øaid joynt Trade, ≈øuch further addition of Stock, as they the ≈øaid Parties ≈øhall think fit. It is now therefore Covenanted, granted and agreed, by and between the ≈øaid Parties to the≈øe pre≈øents, and each of them by and for him≈øelf, his Executors and Admini≈øtrators, doth Covenant, promi≈øe, grant and agree, to and with the other of them by the≈øe pre≈øents in manner and form following: that is to ≈øay, That each of them the ≈øaid Parties ≈øhall and will, on or before the ≈øixth day of, &c. now next en≈øuing, bring and put into the ≈øaid joynt Stock and Trade, each the ≈øum of Two hundred pounds a piece, as afore≈øaid, being his ≈øaid re≈øpective part and ≈øhare of the ≈øaid joynt Stock.

(71.) And that the ≈øaid joynt Stock of FourImployment of the Stock. hundred pound, and ≈øuch further addition of ≈øtock as they the ≈øaid Parties ≈øhall bring and put into the ≈øaid joynt trade, and all the proceed, gains and increa≈øe, which ≈øhall be acquired or gotten, by rea≈øon or means of the imployment of the ≈øaid joynt ≈øtock, and additional ≈øtock in the ≈øaid joynt trade: (except a weekly allowance of Thirty ≈øhillings to each of them the ≈øaid Parties for their particular Hou≈øhold expences, to be taken out of the ≈øaid gains) ≈øhall be from time to time, during the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip, continued, u≈øed and imployed i ‚Ä¢ the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip and joynt Trade, to and for the u≈øe, benefit and behoof of both the ≈øaid Parties to the≈øe pre≈øents, as is here-under mentioned, and ≈øhall not be taken out, converted, u≈øed or imployed by either of the ≈øaid Parties, to or for any other u≈øe, intent or purpo≈øe what≈øoever.

(72.) And, that each of them the ≈øaid PartiesBoth to endeavour to advance the Trade. Where the Trade ≈øhall be u≈øed. Each to be true and faithful to the other. Each to have thirty ≈øhillings a Week. All tran≈øactions to be in both their names. ≈øhall from time to time, during the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip, diligently apply and endeavour him≈øelf in the managing of the ≈øaid joynt trade, and to advance the ≈øame, and the gains and increa≈øe thereof, for the equal benefit and advantage of both the ≈øai ‚Ä¢ Parties:

(73.) And that neither of them the ≈øaid Parties, ≈øhall u≈øe the ≈øaid Trade in any other place, but only in the ≈øaid Me≈ø≈øuage, during the ≈øaid Term, nor ≈øhall u≈øe or exerci≈øe the ≈øaid Trade, with any other Stock, but only for the benefit of both the ≈øaid Parties: And that each of the ≈øaid Parties ≈øhall be true, ju≈øt and faithful to the other of them, in all his Buyings, Sellings, Dealings, Doings and Imployments, in and about the ≈øaid joynt Trade, and that each of the ≈øaid Parties ≈øhall and lawfully may take out of the ≈øaid joynt Stock and Gains, and have the weekly Sum of thirty ≈øhillings for his particular charges of Hou≈øe-keeping.

(74.) And that the ≈øaid joynt Trade ≈øhall be managed and driven, and all Buyings, Sales, Receipts, Payments, Bills, Bonds, Specialties and other A≈ø≈øurances to be had, made or taken for any matter or thing touching the ≈øaid joynt Trade ≈øhall be from time to time, during the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip, entred, had, made and taken in the joynt names of both the ≈øaid Parties to the≈øe pre≈øents.

(75.) And that neither of them the ≈øaid PartiesNeither to become bound with any other Per≈øon. ≈øhall at any time during the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip, become bound or bail, or ≈øurety, or otherwi≈øe ingage him≈øelf with or for any other Per≈øon or Per≈øons, for any Debt or Duty, Matter or Thing not concerning this Copartner≈øhip, without the licen≈øe or con≈øent of the other of the ≈øaid Parties fir≈øt had in that behalf in Writing under his hand: Nor ≈øhall at any Time during the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip compound, relea≈øe or di≈øcharge any Debt or Duty, which ≈øhall be due or owing to the
≈øaid joynt Trade: without the con≈øent of the otherNor to relea≈øe Debts, &c. without the others con≈øent. The ≈øtock not to be attached for particular debts of either. of them the ≈øaid Parties fir≈øt had in that behalf: Other than ≈øo much thereof as ≈øhall be brought into the ≈øaid joynt Stock, within four Dayes next after ≈øuch Relea≈øe made or given for the ≈øame.

(76.) And that the joynt or additional Stock afore≈øaid, or any of the Gains or In ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ea≈øe thereof, ≈øhall not at any Time, during the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip, be attached, ≈øeized, extended, or taken in execution, for or in re≈øpect of the private or particular Debt or Debts, Duty or Duties of either of the ≈øaid Parties not concerning this Copartner≈øhip: But that ≈øuch private and particular Debt and Debts, Duty and Dutys ≈øhall be payed and ≈øatisfied by him or them the ≈øaid Parties who≈øe Debt or Dutyes the ≈øame is or ≈øhall be out of his own particular State not included in the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip.

(77.) And that neither of the ≈øaid PartiesNot to retain Apprentices without con≈øent. ≈øhall at any time during the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip, retain or keep any Servant or Apprentice to be imployed in the ≈øaid joynt Trade, without the con≈øent of the other of them the ≈øaid Parties fir≈øt had and obteined in that ≈øaid behalf.

(78.) And that if either of the ≈øaid PartiesNot to ≈øell upon tru≈øt without con≈øent ≈øhall at any time hereafter, ≈øell or deliver upon Tru≈øt or Credit, any Wares or Commodities, of or belonging to the ≈øaid joynt Trade, without the Co ‚Ä¢ ≈ø ‚Ä¢ nt of the other of the ≈øaid Parties, then ≈øuch of them the ≈øaid Parties, which ≈øhall ≈øell or deliver the ≈øaid Goods or Wares ≈øhall within ≈øix Months next after ≈øuch Sale or Delivery made, pay in unto the ≈øaid joynt Stock ≈øo much of lawful Engli≈øh Money, as each and every ≈øuch Parcel of Wares ≈øhall be ≈øold for, if the Per≈øon or Per≈øons to whom ≈øuch Sail or Delivery ≈øhall be made, ≈øhall not in the mean Time pay and ≈øatisfie for the ≈øame.

(79.) And further it is agreed by the ≈øaid A B. Di≈øcharge of A≈ø≈øe≈øsment for the Me≈ø≈øuage. that he the ≈øaid A. B. ≈øhall and will from time to time during the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip, at his own co≈øts and charges bear pay and di≈øcharge, all Tithes or other Duties due and payable to the Par≈øon for the afore≈øaid Me≈ø≈øuage, and all A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øments for relief of the Poor of the Pari≈øh, ≈øo that the ≈øame A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øments exceed not more than the ≈øaid A. B. now payable and is a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed for the ≈øame. And moreover it is mutually conde≈øcended and agreedThe dividend of the ≈øtock and gaines. by and between the ≈øaid Parties to the≈øe pre≈øents: and each of them for him≈øelf, his Executors and Admini≈øtrators doth covenant and agree to and with the other of them, his Executors and Admini≈øtrators by the≈øe pre≈øents: That each of them the ≈øaid Parties ≈øhall from time to time, during the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip, have a ≈øeveral and equal Part, Right, Title and Intere≈øt in and to the ≈øaid joynt Stock, and Proceed of the ≈øame, and in and to all and every the Gains and Increa≈øe, which ≈øhall be made, rai≈øed or gotten in, by rea≈øon or means of the ≈øaid joynt trade: That is to ≈øay, the ≈øaid A. B. in and to the moyety, or one half Part thereof, and the ≈øaid C. D. in and to the other Moyety, or one half Part thereof: And that each of them the ≈øaid Parties, his Executors and Admini≈øtrators ≈øhall and may at and upon the Di≈ø≈øolution of the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip have, receive and take his ≈øaid re≈øpective Share and Part of all the ≈øaid Premi≈øes, to his and their proper u≈øe and behoof for ever, in ≈øuch manner as hereafter in the≈øe pre≈øents is mentionedNo advantage by Survivor≈øhip. and ≈øet down, without any lett or interruption, of or by the other of them the ≈øaid Parties, his Executors or Admini≈øtrators: and without any benefit or advantage to be taken by Survivor≈øhip, or by either of the ≈øaid Parties ≈øurviving the other of them: any Law, V≈øage or Cu≈øtom of Survivor≈øhip to the contrary thereof in any wi≈øe notwith≈øtanding.

(80.) And that all Debts and Duties whichLo≈ø≈øes equally born, and charges. ≈øhall be owing by them, the ≈øaid Parties, touching the ≈øaid joynt Trade, and all Lo≈ø≈øes by bad Debtors [other than ≈øuch as ≈øhall be tru≈øted by either of them, without the con≈øent of the other of them the ≈øaid Parties] Decay in Wares, or any other inevitable accident, and all charges and expences for repairing of the ≈øaid hou≈øe and ≈øhop, and all other charges nece≈ø≈øarily ari≈øing for any matter or thing touching the ≈øaid joynt Trade: ≈øhall be from time to time during the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip, born, ≈øu≈øteined and payed by and between the ≈øaid Parties to the≈øe pre≈øents, equally out of their ≈øaid joynt Stock and Gains.

(81.) And moreover, That they the ≈øaid PartiesTo keep ≈øhopbooks. ≈øhall from time to time during the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip, at their own charges provide, have and keep ≈øufficient and competent Books of Accompt and Reckoning in writing to be always remaining in the ≈øaid Shop: Wherein they the ≈øaid Parties ≈øhall from time to time, write down and enter, or cau≈øe to be written down and entred, the true Particulars of all ≈øuch Goods, Wares and Merchandizes, that ≈øhall be bought or ≈øold, brought in or delivered out, in or touching the ≈øaid joynt Trade, and of all Sum or Sums of Money, that ≈øhall be received or payed, together with the names of all Per≈øons, unto or from whom any ≈øuch Goods, Wares or Moneys, ≈øhall be received or payed, and all other circum≈øtances of Time and Place any wayes conducing to the manife≈øtation of the State and Proceeding of the ≈øaid Trade: And that each of them the ≈øaid Parties ≈øhall and may from time to time, during the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip, have free Acce≈øs and Recour≈øe unto the ≈øaid Books of Account, to read, peru≈øe, examine and copy out the ≈øame at his Will and Plea≈øure.

(82.) And further, That they the ≈øaid Parties,Every year to perfect the accompt. ≈øhall yearly and every year, during the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip in the Month of September joyn in Accompt together at the ≈øaid ≈øhop: and then and there to make, ca≈øt up, and fully fini≈øh a true, ju≈øt, plain and perfect Accompt and Reckoning in writing of, for and concerning the ≈øaid joynt Trade; and of and for all Moneys, Wares, Goods, Debts, and other E≈øtate what≈øoever, which ≈øhall be then in Copartner≈øhip between the ≈øaid Parties, or joyntly owing or belonging to them, and upon the fini≈øhing of every ≈øuch yearly Accompt, they the ≈øaid Parties ≈øhall write and enter, or cau≈øe to be written down, and entred into two ≈øeveral Books of Account, the true Particulars of every ≈øuch Accompt, and ≈øhall ≈øub≈øcribe their Names in the ≈øaid Books, at the foot of every ≈øuch Account entred therein: and upon the ≈øub≈øcription of their Names, as afore≈øaid, each of the ≈øaid Parties, ≈øhall and may have and take to his own u≈øe one of the ≈øaid Books ≈øub≈øcribed as afore≈øaid.

(83.) And furthermore, that at the end of theThe final account. ≈øaid Term of three years, if they the ≈øaid Parties ≈øhall be both then living, they the ≈øaid Parties, ≈øhall joyn in Accompt together at the Shop afore≈øaid, and ≈øhall then and there make, ca≈øt up and fully fini≈øh between them a true, plain, perfect, and final Accompt and Reckoning in ‚Ä¢ riting, of, for and concerning the ≈øaid joynt Trade, and of, and for all Moneys, Wares, Goods, Debts and other E≈øtate what≈øoever, which ≈øhall be then in Copartner≈øhip between the ≈øaid Parties, or joyntly owing or belonging to them, by rea≈øon or means of the ≈øaid joynt Trade: And of all Debts and Duties, which they the ≈øaid Parties ≈øhall then owe to any Per≈øon or Per≈øons.

(84.) And upon fini≈øhing of the ≈øaid account,To pay Debts, and divide the remainder. they the ≈øaid Parties ≈øhall forthwith ≈øatisfie or take order for the ≈øpeedy ≈øatisfying of all and every the ≈øaid Debts and Duties, ≈øo by them owing: and ≈øhall al≈øo thereupon make a ju≈øt and equal partition, allotment, a≈ø≈øignment and divi≈øion between them the ≈øaid Parties, of all the then re≈øidue and remainder of their ≈øaid partible or joynt Stock and E≈øtate, and increa≈øe thereof: [That is to ≈øay, One moiety or half part thereof unto the ≈øaid A. B. to his own proper u≈øe, and the other moiety or half part thereof unto the ≈øaid C. D. to his own proper u≈øe.]Neither to relea≈øe a Debt a≈ø≈øigned to the other, &c. Each to authorize the other to ≈øue, &c If either die during the three years; the Survivor to take all; paying for a moiety to the Executors of the other.

(85.) And after ≈øuch partition, divi≈øion, a≈ø≈øignment and allotment ≈øo made, neither of the ≈øaid Parties, his Executors or Admini≈øtrators, ≈øhall, without the con≈øent of the other of them, receive, relea≈øe, compound or di≈øcharge any debt or duty, which is or ≈øhall be a≈ø≈øigned or allotted to the other of them re≈øpectively, but that each of them the ≈øaid Parties, his Executors and Admini≈øtrators, ≈øhall from time to time ≈øufficiently authorize the other of them the ≈øaid Parties, his Executors or Admini≈øtrators, upon his or their reque≈øt to ≈øue for, recover, receive and take to his and their own proper u≈øe, all and every the debts and duties, which ≈øhall be allotted to him or them the ≈øaid Parties, his Executors or Admini≈øtrators re≈øpectively, making ≈øuch reque≈øt.

(86.) And further, that if either of the ≈øaid Parties ≈øhall happen to decea≈øe before the end of the ≈øaid three years, and after any yearly account ≈øhall be made between them the ≈øaid Parties, touching the ≈øaid joynt Trade, That then the Survivor of them the ≈øaid Parties‚ñ™ ≈øhall have and take to his own proper u≈øe, all the Moneys, Goods and Wares, which ≈øhall be belonging to the ≈øaid joynt Trade and Copartner≈øhip, at the ≈øame rate and price the ≈øame Goods and Wares did co≈øt, and al≈øo all Debts and Duties which ≈øhall be then d ‚Ä¢ e and owing to the ≈øaid joynt
Trade (except ≈øuch of them as were tru≈øted by the ≈øaid decea≈øed Party, without the con≈øent of the ≈øaid Survivor:) And in con≈øideration thereof, the ≈øaid Survivor, his Executors or Admini≈øtrators, ≈øhall pay, or cau≈øe to be payed to the Executors or Admini≈øtrators of the Per≈øon ≈øo fir≈øt dying at the Shop afore≈øaid, ≈øo much lawful Mony of England as the part and ≈øhare of the Party decea≈øing, of, and in all the ≈øaid Debts that ≈øhall be then owing to the ≈øaid jont Trade, that were accounted good and ≈øpirate Debts: and of, and in all the Moneys, Goods and Wares of the ≈øaid joynt Trade, did, or ≈øhall clearly come and amount unto, by and upon the ≈øaid yearly Account made between the ≈øaid Parties, next before ≈øuch decea≈øe (the Debts owing by the ≈øaid joynt Stock being allowed for, and defalked out of the ≈øaid whole E≈øtate:) The ≈øame Moneys to be payed to the Executors or Admini≈øtrators of the ≈øaid Party decea≈øed, as followeth: That is to ≈øay, One third part thereof at the end of four Months, next after ≈øuch decea≈øe, one other third part thereof at the end of eight Months, nert after ≈øuch decea≈øe, and the remaining third part thereof, at the end of twelve Months next after ≈øuch decea≈øe.

(87.) And, that the ≈øaid Survivor, his ExecutorsHow the Moneys ≈øhall be ≈øecured. or Admini≈øtrators, ≈øhall within twenty Days next after ≈øuch decea≈øe of the other of them the ≈øaid Parties, become bound in a penal Bond, ≈øufficient in the Law, of double the Principal, and with ≈øufficient Sureties to the Executors or Admini≈øtrators of the per≈øon ≈øo fir≈øt dying, as well for the true payment of the ≈øaid three ≈øeveral ≈øums, in manner and form afore≈øaid, as al≈øo for the ≈øaving harmle≈øs, and keeping indempnified, of the Executors and Admini≈øtrators, Lands, Tenements, Goods and Chattels of the ≈øaid fir≈øtSecurity again≈øt joynt Debts. de ‚Ä¢ ea≈øing Party, of, and from all and every the Debts and Duties, which were joyntly owing by them the ≈øaid Parties at the time of ≈øuch decea≈øe,
of, for and concerning the ≈øaid joynt trade, and of and from all Accounts, Suits, Iudgments, Executions and Demands, for, touching or concerning the ≈øame.

(88.) In con≈øideration whereof, the ExecutorsThe Executors of the Party decea≈øing to relea≈øe all demands. or Admini≈øtrators of the ≈øaid decea≈øed Party, ≈øhall upon receipt of the ≈øaid Security, ≈øufficiently and in due form of Law, remi≈øs and relea≈øe unto the ≈øaid Survivor, his Executors and Admini≈øtrators, all the part, ≈øhare, right, title, intere≈øt, claim and demand what≈øoever, which they the ≈øaid Executors and Admini≈øtrators o ‚Ä¢ the decea≈øed Partie, and every or any of them, have or hath, or may, can, might ≈øhould or ought to have in, to or out of all and every, or any of the Stock E≈øtate, Mony, Goods, Wares and Debts which were in or belonging to the ≈øaid joynt Trade, or Copartner≈øhip, at the decea≈øe of the Party ≈øoExcept de≈øperate Debts which are to be divided. fir≈øt dying, or at any time before, except ≈øuch Debts as were accounted de≈øperate, which by the agreement of bath the ≈øaid Parties to the≈øe pre≈øents, for them, their Executors and Admini≈øtrators, are to be equally divided between the Survivor and the Executors and Admini≈øtrators of the decea≈øed Party, as they or any of them ≈øhall be received or gotten in.

(89.) And it is further covenanted and agreedHow the E≈øtate is to be divided, if either die before account made. by and between the ≈øaid Parties to the≈øe pre≈øents: That if either of the ≈øaid Parties ≈øhall happen to depart this life before any yearly Account ≈øhall happen to be made between the ≈øaid Parties touching the ≈øaid joynt Trade, that then the ≈øurviving Party, his Executors and Admini≈øtrators ≈øhall have and take to his and their own u≈øe and b ‚Ä¢ hoof, all the Moneys, Goods, Wares, Debts and other E≈øtate what≈øoever, in or belonging to the ≈øaid joynt Trade, at the time of ≈øuch decea≈øe, and ≈øhall ≈øatisfie the Debts joyntly owing by the ≈øaid Parties, as afore≈øaid, at the time of ≈øuch decea≈øe, and ≈øhall truly pay unto the Executors or Admini≈øtrators of the fir≈øt decea≈øed
Party, within one year then next en≈øuing, ≈øo much lawful Engli≈øh Money, as the Stock that then ≈øhall be brought into the ≈øaid joynt Trade by the Partie ≈øo decea≈øing did come and amount unto, and that ≈øuch ≈øecurity ≈øhall be given for the ≈øame, and for the ≈øaving harmle≈øs of the Executors or Admini≈øtrators of the decea≈øed Partie, of and from the Debts and Duties joyntly owing by the ≈øaid Parties as afore≈øaid, as is above mentioned to be given for the like purpo≈øes, in Ca≈øe the decea≈øe of the Partie ≈øo fir≈øt dying had happened after the making of an yearlyRelea≈øe. Accompt, as afore≈øaid: And that then al≈øo the like Relea≈øe ≈øhall be made and given by the Executors or Admini≈øtrators of the fir≈øt decea≈øing Partie to the ≈øurviving Partie, his Executors and Admini≈øtrators, as is above mentioned.

(90.) And the ≈øaid A. B. for him≈øelf, hisTouching the Me≈ø≈øuage if A. B. do, &c. Executors and Admini≈øtrators doth covenant and grant to and with the ≈øaid C. D. his Executors and Admini≈øtrators by the≈øe pre≈øents: That if the ≈øaid A. B. ≈øhall happen to decea≈øe within the ≈øaid term of three years, that then the Executors or Admini≈øtrators of the ≈øaid A. B. ≈øhall within twenty Dayes, next after his decea≈øe, demi≈øe and grant unto the ≈øaid C. D. (if he ≈øhall be then living) his Executors and Admini≈øtrators, all the ≈øaid Me≈ø≈øuage or Tenement above mentioned, for and during the then Re≈øidue of the ≈øaid Term of three years at, for and under the yearly rent of twenty three pound of lawful Moneys of England to be by the ≈øaid demi≈øe re≈øerved quarterly to be payed, and with ≈øuch Covenants to be in≈øerted in the ≈øaid Demi≈øe on the Part and behalf of the ≈øaid C. D. his Executors Admini≈øtrators and A≈ø≈øigns to be performed and kept, as are conteined in the Lea≈øe, whereby the ≈øaid A. B. holdeth the ≈øame, ≈øo that the ≈øaid C. D. do upon the Sealing and Delivery of the ≈øaid Lea≈øe, ≈øeal and deliver the Counter-Party thereof, as his act
and deed unto the Le≈ø≈øor or Le≈ø≈øors therein named.

(91.) And it is covenanted, concluded and agreedHow to compo≈øe differences. by and between the ≈øaid Parties to the≈øe pre≈øents, for them, their Executors and Admini≈øtrators: That if any Variance, Strife, Difference or Controver≈ø ‚Ä¢ e, ≈øhall at any Time hereafter, during the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip, or at the end thereof happen to grow, ari≈øe, or be between the ≈øaid Parties, to the≈øe pre≈øents, their Executors or Admini≈øtrators, or any of them, upon, touching or concerning their ≈øaid joynt Trade or any their buyings, ≈øellings, accompts, matters or things relating thereunto, or for, or touching any Covenant, Matter or Thing in the≈øe pre≈øents conteined: That then and ≈øo often they the ≈øaid Parties to the≈øe pre≈øents, their Executors or Admini≈øtrators ≈øhall upon rea≈øonable reque≈øt made by either or any of them unto the other of them before any Suit ≈øhall be commenced for, or touching the ≈øame, elect, name and chu≈øe two indifferent Per≈øons to hear and determine the ≈øame differences and matters of difference, one of which Arbitrators the ≈øaid A. B. his Executors or Admini≈øtratorsArbitrators. ≈øhall chu≈øe and name. And the other of the ≈øaid Arbitrators the ≈øaid C. D. his Executors or Admini≈øtrators ≈øhall name and chu≈øe: And that each of the ≈øaid Parties his Executors and Admini≈øtrators ≈øhall re≈øpectively ≈øtand to and abide, perform and keep ≈øuch award, order, determination and judgment, which the ≈øaid two Arbitrators ≈øhall make and give in writing under their hands and ≈øeals unto the Parties ≈øubject by the≈øe pre≈øents thereunto, upon and touching the ≈øaid differences and matters in difference, ≈øo that the ≈øaid award be made and given, as afore≈øaid in writing, within thirty Dayes next after the Choice and Nomination of the ≈øaid Arbitrators in that behalf. And in ca≈øe the ≈øaid Arbitrators ≈øhall not make and give forth their ≈øaid award as afore≈øaid; within time before limited for
the doing thereof, then each of the ≈øaid PartiesUmpire. his Executors and Admini≈øtrators ≈øhall and will ≈øtand to, abide, perform and keep ≈øuch Award, Order and Vmperage, as ≈øuch one Per≈øon Vmpire to be elected and cho≈øen by the ≈øaid Arbitrator ≈øhall make and give forth in Writing, as afore≈øaid, under his hand and ≈øeal upon and touching the ≈øaid differences and matters in difference within twenty dayes next after the end of the ≈øaid thirty Dayes: And in ca≈øe the ≈øaid Vmpire ≈øhall not make and give forth, as afore≈øaid, his ≈øaid Award and Vmpirage, within the time above limited for the doing thereof, that then each and every of them the ≈øaid Parties, his Executors and Admini≈øtrators ≈øhall and will for his and their Parts ≈øtand to, abide, perform and keep ≈øuchMa≈øter and Wardens of the company, &c. Award, Order, Determination and Iudgment as the Ma≈øter and Wardens of the Company of Merchant-Taylors in London, or the major Part of them ≈øhall make and give forth, as afore≈øaid, in writing under their hands and ≈øeals, upon and touching the ≈øaid differences and matters in difference within two Months next after the end of the ≈øaid twenty Dayes.

(92.) Provided neverthele≈øs, and it is covenanted,If either prove unfaithful, Copartner≈øhip to cea≈øe. concluded and agreed by and between the ≈øaid Parties to the≈øe Pre≈øents for them, their Executors and Admini≈øtrators: That if either of the ≈øaid Parties ≈øhall be untrue, uniu≈øt or unfaithful unto the other of them, in any buyings, ≈øales, receipts or payments belonging to, or concerning the ≈øaid Copartner-≈øhip: That then or at any times afterwards, upon notice of di≈ølike given thereof by either of them to the other of them the ≈øaid Parties, and de≈øire thereupon ≈øignified that the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip ≈øhall determine: The ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip and joynt Trade ≈øhall cea≈øe, determine and be di≈ø≈øolved: And that the like Account, Partition and Divi≈øion ≈øhall be made between the ≈øaid Parties to the≈øe Pre≈øents, their Executors and Admini≈øtrators, of the ≈øaid joynt
Stock and Proceed thereof, and ≈øhall do all other things concerning the ≈øaid joynt Trade, in ≈øuch manner and form, to all intents and purpo≈øes in every re≈øpect, as they are to do at the end of the ≈øaid three years. And that from and after the end and di≈ø≈øolution of the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip, in manner and form afore≈øaid, the ≈øaid Term and Intere≈øt granted unto the ≈øaid C. D. of and in Part of the ≈øaid dwelling hou≈øe and ≈øhop in manner afore≈øaid, ≈øhall likewi≈øe cea≈øe, determine and be void.

div.head: Another between two Brewers.
div.p:
(93.) This Indenture made, &c. Between A. B. Re ‚Ä¢ ital that they are joyntly ≈øeized of a Brewhou≈øe, &c. of the one Part; and C. D. of the other Part: whereas the ≈øaid A. B. and C. D. do ≈øtand joyntly intere≈øted and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of and in one Me≈ø≈øuage or Tenement with the Appurtenances, and of and in one Brew-hou≈øe, ≈øcituate in, &c. (late in the occupation of E. F.) for divers years yet induring, and al≈øo of and in one Copper and divers and ≈øundry brewing Ve≈ø≈øels, Goods, Implements, and hou≈øhold-≈øtuff, by virtue of one Lea≈øe bearing Date, &c. made between the ≈øaid E. F. on the one Part, and the ≈øaid A. B. and C. D. on the other Part: And whereupon the yearly rent of, &c. is re≈øerved to be payed: and likewi≈øe are po≈ø≈øe≈øt of, and intere≈ø≈øed in a certain parcel of ground, ≈øtables, hay-lofts, and other Rooms now u≈øed with the ≈øaid Brewhou≈øe, as Part of and appertaining
to the ≈øame, for certain years al≈øo yet induring by vertue of one other Lea≈øe to them made by the ≈øaid E. F. bearing date, &c. under the yearly Rent of, &c. as by the ≈øaid two ≈øeveral Indentures of Lea≈øe, relation being thereunto had, more fully and at large it doth and may appear.

(94.) Now witne≈ø≈øeth, that the ≈øaid partiesTheir joyning in Copartner≈øhip. to the≈øe pre≈øents, out of love and affection which they have unto each other, and confidence and tru≈øt in each other repo≈øed, and to the end that the ≈øaid parties may, by Gods ble≈ø≈øing, increa≈øe in Stock, and be the better inabled to maintain them≈øelves and their Families, Have concluded, conde≈øcended and agreed together, and by the≈øe pre≈øents, do conclude, conde≈øcend and agree to be Copartners and joynt Dealers in the mi≈øtery or trade of brewing of Beer and Ale in the ≈øaid Brew-hou≈øe, immediately from and after the day of the Date hereof, for and during the time and term of, &c. from thence next en≈øuing, and fully to be compleat and ended (if both the ≈øaid parties ≈øhall and do ≈øo long live.)

(95.) And to that intent and purpo≈øe, the ≈øaidStock put in. A. B. for his part and portion of the Stock to be imployed in the ≈øaid joynt Trade, hath put in the ≈øum of Two hundred pounds of lawful Moneys of England, and likewi≈øe the ≈øaid C. D. for his part and portion of the ≈øaid Stock, hath put in the like ≈øum of Two hundred pounds of like lawful Moneys of England, to be likewi≈øe u≈øed and imployed in the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip and joynt Trade.

(96.) It is now Covenanted, granted andTo have equal parts. agreed by and between the ≈øaid parties to the≈øe pre≈øents, And ‚Ä¢ ither of them for him≈øelf, his Executors, Admini≈øtrators and A≈ø≈øigns re≈øpectively, doth Covenant and grant to and with the other of them, his Executors, Admini≈øtrators and A≈ø≈øigns by the≈øe pre≈øents, that they and either of them, their ≈øeveral Executors and Admini≈øtrators,
≈øhall be alike intere≈ø≈øed, and have, retain and a≈ø≈øume to their own ≈øeveral u≈øes: equal ≈øhares parts and portions, of, in and to the ≈øaid ≈øeveral Stocks, by them ≈øeverally put in, to be imployed in this Copartner≈øhip, and of all and every ≈øuch other ≈øum and ≈øums of Mony, as thereunto ≈øhall hereafter be by them added or put, and of, in and to all the gains, profits and increa≈øe to come or grow thereof, or of any part thereof, or by any advantage ari≈øing by the ≈øaid Partner≈øhip.

(97.) And, for the ≈øure and more effectual proceedingTo be faithful in, and indu≈øtrious for the advancement of the Trade. in the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip, to the be≈øt benefit and advantage of the ≈øaid ≈øeveral parties to the≈øe pre≈øents, either of the ≈øaid parties for him≈øelf, and for his ≈øeveral Executors and Adminini≈øtrators re≈øpectively, doth Covenant, promi≈øe and grant to and with the other of them, his Executors and Admini≈øtrators by the≈øe pre≈øents, in manner and form following: that is to ≈øay, That each of them ≈øhall and will from time to time during the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip, be true and faithful to the other of them, in every thing, in, about and relating to the ≈øaid Trade and mi≈øtery of Brewing, and all other things which ≈øhall any waies concern the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip, and ≈øhall do and perform his and their be≈øt endeavours from time to time, during the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip, to the be≈øt of their wit, knowledge, power and skill in Brewing of Ale and Beer, or either of them in the ≈øaid Brew-hou≈øe, and in uttering and ≈øelling of the ≈øame, and in all other things nece≈ø≈øary and convenient to be put in ure, touching or concerning the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip and joynt occupying, for the bringing in of gains, and as much as in them or either of them lieth, for the avoiding and preventing of lo≈øs.

(98.) And that all lo≈ø≈øes and dammagesLo≈ø≈øes, charges, &c. to be equally born. which ≈øhall happen, or come in the ≈øaid joynt trade and management thereof, either by evil or bad Debtors, or other Ca≈øualties how≈øoever (≈øo as it be not through the wilful negligence or deceit of either of the ≈øaid Parties) and that all Sub≈øidies, Taxes, and other Impo≈øitions to be charged and impo≈øed upon the ≈øaid Parties, or either of them; by rea≈øon of this Copartner≈øhip, and joynt trade or ≈øtock; and all other charges for Rent of the ≈øaid Brew-hou≈øe, and the ≈øaid Me≈ø≈øuage or Tenement, and other Hou≈øes and Grounds, which are and ≈øhall be u≈øed with the ≈øaid Brew-hou≈øe‚ñ™ and all charges of Reparations to be done by the Covenants in the ≈øaid ≈øeveral Lea≈øes; or either of them contained; and all other nece≈ø≈øary Charges to be expended in Hou≈øe-keeping at the ≈øaid Brew-hou≈øe, and all payments and nece≈ø≈øary Charges of Corn, Coles, Hops, Ve≈ø≈øels, Vten≈ø ‚Ä¢ ls, Servants wages‚ñ™ Candles, Drays, Hor≈øes and other nece≈ø≈øary charges what≈øoever, in and about the ≈øaid trade of Brewing, during this Copartner≈øhip; ≈øhall be equally and indifferently ≈øu≈øtained, born, payed and di≈øcharged by and between the ≈øaid Parties, out of their ≈øeveral parts of the Gains or Stock, part and part, like as Copartners:

(99.) And al≈øo, it is mutually agreed by andNone to take out of the Stock and Gains, without the others con≈øent. between the ≈øaid Parties to the≈øe pre≈øents, that neither of them ≈øhall at any time or times, during the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip, withdraw; or take out or from the ≈øaid principal Stock, or the gains thereof, any ≈øum or ≈øums of Mony, other than for the nece≈ø≈øary u≈øes afore≈øaid, without the mutual con≈øent and agreement of the other of them fir≈øt had, and obtained: and ≈øuch of them as by ≈øuch con≈øent as afore≈øaid, ≈øhall at any time take out of the ≈øame, ≈øhall immediately enter into a Book for that purpo≈øe to be kept, the quantity ≈øo taken out, to the end that the other of the ≈øaid Parties, may thereby take notice thereof.

(100.) And it is further Covenanted, granted,Books of Account to be kept. concluded and fully agreed, by and between the ≈øaid parties to the≈øe pre≈øents, that they and either of them, ≈øhall, as near as they may, from time to time, keep, or cau≈øe to be kept, true, ju≈øt and perfect Books of Account and Reckoning in writing to the uttermo≈øt of their ≈øeveral knowledge, of all the Payments, Receipts and Debts, to or from them due or owing, and of all Gains, Lo≈ø≈øes, and other things touching their joynt trade and dealing in this pre≈øent Copartner≈øhip: which Books ≈øhall be extant from time to time, and at all times convenient, for the ≈øaid Parties, or their A≈ø≈øigns, to peru≈øe and examine.

(101.) And, that once every quarter of a yearTo Accompt once a quarter. at the lea≈øt, during the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip: that is to ≈øay, At the Fea≈øts of, &c. or within twenty days next after every of the ≈øaid Fea≈øts (or oftner if need ≈øhall be) upon reque≈øt made by one of the ≈øaid Parties unto the other of them, they the ≈øaid Parties ≈øhall joyn in reckoning together, and make and deliver either of them to the other of them, to the be≈øt of their ≈øeveral knowledge, true, perfect and plain Account or Accounts in writing, of, for, and concerning the ≈øaid principal Stock, and all other things in Partner≈øhip between them, and of the Gains and Lo≈ø≈øes thereof, or thereby ari≈øing; and of all Debts to them due or owing, and by and from them to be due and owing to any per≈øon or per≈øons, and of all the Receipts, Payments, Dealings and Doings, in or concerning the ≈øaid Brew-hou≈øe, or otherwi≈øe touching or concerning this their joyn ‚Ä¢ trade or dealings, without any voluntary concealment, withdrawing or unju≈øt deteyning of any part of the ≈øaid principal Stock; or of any gain, profit or Commodity, which ≈øhould or ought in any wi≈øe come to the equal ≈øhare of the ≈øaid Parties to the≈øe pre≈øents, by the true intent and meaning of the≈øe pre≈øents.

(102.) And moreover, it is agreed betweenHow Mony ‚Ä¢ ound in either of their hands, &c. ≈øhall be di≈øpo≈øed of. the ≈øaid Parties, that what≈øoever ≈øum or ≈øums of Mony, at or upon the foot of any Account or Accounts, concerning this Copartner≈øhip, ≈øhall be found to be remaining in the hands of any Clerk or Clerks, or in the hands of any of the ≈øaid Copartners, or of their A≈ø≈øignee or A≈ø≈øigns, not expended about the bu≈øine≈øs of the ≈øaid joynt trade and Copartner≈øhip, and before not accounted for by the ≈øaid Copartners, the ≈øame ≈øhall be forthwith, from time to time, equally and indifferently divided between the ≈øaid Copartners, part and part like: or run and be continued in Stock, as the ≈øaid Parties can be≈øt agree concerning the ≈øame.

(103.) And it is Covenanted, granted andNo advantage by Survivor≈øhip. fully agreed, by and between the ≈øaid Parties to the≈øe pre≈øents, for them, their Executors and Admini≈øtrators re≈øpectively, that if it ≈øhall fortune that either of the ≈øaid Parties ≈øhall die or decea≈øe, during the time of this Copartner≈øhip, before any ≈øeparation or divi≈øion ≈øhall be made between them of the ≈øaid Stock, and common Dealings (the other of them ≈øurviving) that in ≈øuch ca≈øe no advantage by the ≈øurvivor of the ≈øaid Parties, in right, or in re≈øpect of his Survivor≈øhip, ≈øhall hold or take place, or be by him or them challenged, taken or demanded, but that ≈øuch part and portion of, in, and to the ≈øaid principal Stock, and the gains and increa≈øe thereof, and al≈øo of the afore≈øaid Me≈ø≈øuages or Tenements, which is, or ≈øhall be due or belonging to ≈øuch of the ≈øaid Parties ≈øo decea≈øed, at the time of his death ≈øhall come and be payed to the Executors, Admini≈øtrators or A≈ø≈øigns of the ≈øaid decea≈øed Copartner, in ≈øuch like, and in ≈øo large, ≈øimple and beneficial manner, as the ≈øame ≈øhould or ought to have grown due, to be payed or ≈øati≈øfied unto the ≈øaid decea≈øed Copartner him≈øelf, if he had been living at the ≈øu ‚Ä¢ cea≈øe or determination of this Copartner≈øhip.

(104.) And moreover it is covenanted and agreedDivi≈øion to be made at the end of the Copartner≈øhip. by and between the ≈øaid Parties to the≈øe pre≈øents, and either of the ≈øaid Parties for him≈øelf, his Executors and Admini≈øtrators re≈øpectively covenanteth and granteth, to and with the other of them, his Executors and Admini≈øtrators by the≈øe pre≈øents: That within the ≈øpace of ≈øix Months next after the end‚ñ™ or giving over of this Copartner≈øhip, be it upon the ex≈øpiration of the ≈øaid Term of ≈øix Years, or by the decea≈øe of either of the ≈øaid Parties, or otherwi≈øe how≈øoever, the ≈øaid Parties if they be living, or if either of them ≈øhall happen to be decea≈øed, then the Survivor of them, and the Executors or Admini≈øtrators of the decea≈øed Copartner, ≈øhall con≈øent and agree together, and ≈øhall upon rea≈øonable reque≈øt to be made by the one to the otherFour men to apprai≈øe the goods. of them, make choice and election of four indifferent men, whereof two ≈øhall be cho≈øen by the ≈øaid A. P. his Executors or Admini≈øtrators, and the other two by the ≈øaid C. D. his Executors or Admini≈øtrators, to make and ≈øet down an indifferent Apprai≈øement and Valuation of all and ≈øingular the Goods, Implements and Chattels, which then ≈øhall be and remain in Partner≈øhip between them (if otherwi≈øe between them≈øelves they cannot agree therein) the Goods, Coppers, Brewing Ve≈ø≈øels, Implements and Hou≈øhold-≈øtuff, which are expre≈ø≈øed in the Schedule‚ñ™ or Inventory annexed to the ≈øaid Indenture of Lea≈øe only excep ‚Ä¢ ed: and that upon and after Apprai≈øement thereof, the ≈øaid Copartners, or the Surviving Copartner and Executors or Admini≈øtrators of the decea≈øed Copartner (if either of them ≈øhall happen to die) ≈øhall make and ca≈øt Lots between them, to take or refu≈øe the ≈øaid Goods ≈øo to be apprai≈øed, as the ≈øame ≈øhall be valued: And that he or they of them, to who≈øe Lot the ≈øaid Goods ≈øhall happen to fall, his or their Executors or Admini≈øtrators, ≈øhall accept, receive and take the ≈øame: And al≈øo ≈øhall within ≈øix Months then next
following, ≈øatisfie and pay, or cau≈øe to be ≈øatisfiedLots ca≈øt which of them ≈øhall have the goods, and pay a Moyety to the other. Divi≈øion of debts. and payed, unto the other of them the ≈øaid Copartners, his Executors or Admini≈øtrators, the Moyety or half Part of all ≈øuch Money, as the ≈øaid Goods ≈øhall be valued and apprai≈øed at: at or within the Brew-hou≈øe before mentioned, without any fraud or covin. And ≈øhall al≈øo then make equal divi≈øion between them of the Money then belonging to the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip, and al≈øo of the debts then owing to the ≈øaid Copartners, for or in re≈øpect of the ≈øaid partible Stock or Trade: and of all and ≈øingular other the things, now intended or expre≈ø≈øed by the≈øe pre≈øents to be partible and divided between the ≈øaid Parties to the≈øe pre≈øents in re≈øpect of the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip: or otherwi≈øe thereof to deal and di≈øpo≈øe as then they ≈øhall find to be mo≈øt behooveful for them.

(105.) And further, that within convenientAnother way of account and divi≈øion. time after the giving over, ending or determination of this Copartner≈øhip, intended by the≈øe pre≈øents: the ≈øaid Parties or the Survivor of them, his Executors and Admini≈øtrators ≈øhall and will upon rea≈øonable reque≈øt therefore to be made, the one of them to the other of them [if they be both living] or if either of them ≈øhall be decea≈øed, then to the Executors and Admini≈øtrators of the ≈øaid Party decea≈øed, a true, plain, and perfect Account in writing of the ≈øaid whole Stock, Gains, Debts, Credits, and all other things which ≈øhall be then in Copartner≈øhip between them, or belonging to the ≈øaid partible Stock and Trade, and within ≈øix Months after the end, determination or expiration of the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip (be it how≈øoever) ≈øhall make an equal and indifferent ≈øeparation and divi≈øion of all the ≈øaid partible Stock, Gains, Debts, and other the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes, intended or expre≈øt to be in Copartner≈øhip: and a≈ø≈øign, allot and allow, or cau≈øe to be a≈ø≈øigned, allotted and allowed, one of them to the other of them the ≈øaid Parties, ‚Ä¢ r if either of them be decea≈øed, then to the Executor ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ,
Admini≈øtrators or A≈ø≈øigns of the decea≈øed Copartner, the moiety of the afore≈øaid Me≈ø≈øuages or Tenements: and ≈øo much of the ≈øaid whole part and portion of the ≈øaid Stock and Gains, and of all and ≈øingular other the premi≈ø≈øes which are expre≈ø≈øed or meant to be in Copartner≈øhip, as to any of the ≈øaid Parties ≈øhall be due and appertaining, or of right belonging for his port, property and portion, of, and in the ≈øame, according to the true intent and meaning of the≈øe pre≈øents (fir≈øt deducting and defalking ≈øo much as ≈øhall and may ≈øatisfie all the Debts, which they the ≈øaid Parties, or any of them ≈øhall owe, or be indebted for, or in re≈øpect of the ≈øaid partible trade or dealing.)

(106.) And that the Survivor of the ≈øaidSurvivor to gather in debts. Parties, his Executors and Admini≈øtrators, ≈øhall do his and their be≈øt endeavour to collect and gather in all the Debts, which were or ≈øhall be owing to the ≈øaid Copartners, or any of them in re≈øpect of the ≈øaid partible Stock or Trade: and after defalcation made of ≈øo much either in goods, ≈øtock, mony, or otherwi≈øe, as ≈øhall ≈øuffice to ≈øati≈øfie and pay the Debts which ≈øhall be then truly owing by them or either of them, in re≈øpect of the ≈øaid partible Stock, Trade or Dealing, ≈øhall as the ≈øaid Debts, or any part thereof ≈øhall be had or received, make payment of one half part thereof (nece≈ø≈øary Charges in ≈øuing for, and getting in of the ≈øame, being fir≈øt deducted and allowed) to the Executors, Admini≈øtrators or A≈ø≈øigns of ≈øuch of t ‚Ä¢ e ≈øaid Parties as ≈øhall fir≈øt happen to decea≈øe.To a≈ø≈øign to Executors of Party dying part of the Debts, &c.

(107.) And, that the ≈øaid Survivor, his Executors and Admini≈øtrators, if it be reque≈øted of him or them, for all the re≈øidue of Debts and things what≈øoever, which are or ≈øhall be owing or belonging to them or any of them, according to the true meaning of the≈øe pre≈øents, in re≈øpect of the ≈øaid intended Copartner≈øhip, whereof the Executors, Admini≈øtrators or A≈ø≈øigns of the ≈øaid Copartner
fir≈øt decea≈øed, as is afore≈øaid, ≈øhall not have had and received, his and their part, ≈øhall and will make and deliver to the Executors, Admini≈øtrators or A≈ø≈øigns of the fir≈øt decea≈øed Copartner, at his and their own proper Co≈øt and charges, ≈øuch a≈ø≈øignment, conveyance and a≈ø≈øurance of ≈øuch part thereof, as to the Executors or Admini≈øtrators of ≈øuch Copartner ≈øo fir≈øt decea≈øing, in truth ought to belong, as by the Executors, Admini≈øtrators or A≈ø≈øigns of the ≈øaid fir≈øt decea≈øed Partner, or the learned Coun≈øel in the Law, of them or any of them, ≈øhall be rea≈øonably devi≈øed or advi≈øed.

(108.) And moreover, it is Covenanted,All things tran≈øacted to be in both their Names. granted and agreed, by and between the ≈øaid Parties to the≈øe pre≈øents, That all ≈øuch Malt, Hops, Coals, Beer, and other thing and things what≈øoever, which at any time or times hereafter ≈øhall be bought or ≈øold, u≈øed or imployed, in or about the ≈øaid joynt trade, or occupying, ≈øhall be had and done by the joynt con≈øent of the ≈øaid Parties (if the ≈øame conveniently may be done) and not otherwi≈øe. And that all and every per≈øon and per≈øons, that ≈øhall hereafter become Debtor or Debtors, to or for the ≈øaid principal Stocks, or any part thereof, or for any Beer or other things that ≈øhall ari≈øe, come, grow or increa≈øe thereby, or be ≈øold out of, or for the ≈øame, or the proceed thereof, ≈øhall be made debtors to both the ≈øaid Parties for the ≈øame, according to the true intent and meaning of the≈øe pre≈øents: And that all Bonds, Bills, A≈ø≈øurances and Securities, that ≈øhall be made or taken for any Beer, or other Debts: or for or concerning the true or good ≈øervice of any Clerk or Clerks, or other Servant or Servants, which ≈øhall be put in tru≈øt to ≈øerve in the affairs of the ≈øaid Brewhou≈øe, or joynt Trade, ≈øhall be made and taken to both the ≈øaid Parties, and in both their Names, and ≈øhall be delivered and ≈øafely kept to both their u≈øes: And, that neither of the ≈øaid
Parties, without the con≈øent of the other ofAcquittances. them, his Executors or Admini≈øtrators, ≈øhall make, ≈øeal or deliver any Acquittance or Acquittances, Relea≈øe or Relea≈øes, Di≈øcharge or Di≈øcharges what≈øoever, to any per≈øon or per≈øons, their Executors or Admini≈øtrators (which is, or ≈øhall be Debtor or Debtors) for the ≈øaid ≈øtock, or any part or parcel thereof, or for any Mony thereunto to be added or put to the increa≈øe thereof, or that thereupon, or by means thereof ≈øhall ari≈øe, come or grow, of, for, or concerning any Bond or A≈ø≈øurance, as afore≈øaid, to be taken in the Names of the ≈øaid Parties for the ≈øaid partible u≈øe, or for any thing appertaining, or which ≈øhall appertain to the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip, whereby to defeat or defraud the other Copartner, his Executors or Admini≈øtrators, of his or their ju≈øt part, or of any part thereof, or for any le≈ø≈øer or ≈ømaller ≈øum or ≈øums of Mony, than the per≈øon or per≈øons ≈øo indebted ≈øhall truly owe, or ≈øtand charged to pay (rea≈øonable Compo≈øitions and Abatements, of, and for Debts, due and to be due, owing and appertaining to the ≈øaid Parties, in re≈øpect of their ≈øaid joynt trade, for leaking, or return of mu≈øty Beer, or naughty Beer, and ≈øuch like, to be made without fraud or covin, and no further di≈øadvantage or profit of the one Copartner than the other, his Executors or Admini≈øtrators only excepted) But that either of them the ≈øaid Parties ≈øhall do his be≈øt endeavour for the Recovery and getting in of the ≈øame, and after the ≈øame ≈øo recovered, ≈øhall deliver the moiety thereof (all rea≈øonable co≈øts and charges deducted, according to the true intent and meaning of the≈øe pre≈øents) to the other of them, his Executors or Admini≈øtrators.

(109.) And fora≈ømuch as the ≈øaid Parties toDetermination of Controver≈øies. the≈øe pre≈øents, are minded and intended to be Brewers, and the knowledge of all matters concerning the ≈øaid Trade and Mi≈øtery, is be≈øt acquainted to men of the ≈øame Trade, they the ≈øaid Parties do Covenant, conclude and agree, for them, their Executors and Admini≈øtrators by the≈øe pre≈øents re≈øpectively, that if at any time or times hereafter, any controver≈øie or debate ≈øhall happen to ari≈øe or grow between them the ≈øaid Parties, for or touching the premi≈ø≈øes, or any part thereof, or any thing herein contained or ≈øpecified, that then and ≈øo often the ≈øaid Parties, their Executors and Admini≈øtrators, and every of them, ≈øhall ≈øhew the cau≈øe of ≈øuch controver≈øie (before any ≈øuit at Law ≈øhall be commenced touching the ≈øame) unto four hone≈øt and di≈øcreet men of the ≈øame Trade or Mi≈øtery, whom they ≈øhall nominate, appoint and make choice of, to hear and determine ≈øuch variances, doubts and controver≈øies as ≈øhall happen to ari≈øe between them: And ≈øhall ≈øtand to, abide, perform and keep all and every ≈øuch award, order, final end and judgment, as in that behalf ≈øhall be ≈øet down by the ≈øaid four Men, ≈øo to be nominated, cho≈øen and appointed between them, to have the hearing and determination of ≈øuch controver≈øies, ≈øo as they do order, judge and give up their award thereupon in writing unto the ≈øaid Parties ≈øubject thereunto, within forty days next after ≈øuch reference, as afore≈øaid, made unto them.

div.head: Another form of Copartner≈øhip between a Pewterer and another per≈øon, who puts in the Stock, and the Pewterer manageth the Trade.

B. for and in re≈øpect of the love and good affectionThe Stock put in by one; and how to be imployed. which he beareth unto the ≈øaid C. D. and for his better preferment and advantage in his trade and profe≈ø≈øion, before the en≈øealing and delivery hereof, hath disbur≈øed and delivered unto the ≈øaid C. D. in the ≈øaid Art, Trade or Profe≈ø≈øion of a Pewterer, in buying of Pewter, and other things needful to be u≈øed in and about the ≈øaid Art or Trade, and in duying, ca≈øting, ≈øoldering, vending and ≈øelling of all ≈øuch Wares, Goods and Merchandizes (incident to the ≈øaid Art, Trade or Profe≈ø≈øion of a Pewterer) as by the ≈øaid A. B. and C. D. ≈øhall be thought meet and convenient in a Shop for that purpo≈øe, to be made ready at the co≈øt and charges of the ≈øaid C. D. in or about the now Me≈ø≈øuage, Tenement or Yard of the ≈øaid C. D. ≈øcituate and being in, &c. from the day of the Date of the≈øe pre≈øents, unto the full end and term of Ten years from thence next en≈øuing, and fully to be compleat and ended, if the ≈øaid C. D. do and ≈øhall ≈øo long live.

(111.) In con≈øideration whereof, the ≈øaid C. To do his endeavour to advance the Trade. D. for him≈øelf, his Executors and Admini≈øtrators, doth Covenant, grant and agree, to and with the ≈øaid A. B. his Executors, Admini≈øtrators and A≈ø≈øigns, and to and with every of them by the≈øe pre≈øents, in manner and form following: that is to ≈øay, That he the ≈øaid C. D. ≈øhall and will at all times hereafter, and from time to time during the ≈øaid term of ten years (if the ≈øaid C. D. ≈øhall ≈øo long live) diligently and carefully imploy him≈øelf, and do his be≈øt endeavour, to the uttermo≈øt of his power and skill, in and about the buying, ≈øelling, ca≈øting, ≈øoldering and fini≈øhing of all ≈øuch Works, Wares, Goods and Merchandizes, as are incident or belonging to the Art, Trade and Profe≈ø≈øion afore≈øaid, and in doing, executing and performing of every other thing which ≈øhall be nece≈ø≈øary to be done and put in ure, in, about or concerning the ≈øaid Art, Trade or Profe≈ø≈øion of a Pewterer, for the rai≈øing of Gain, and, as much as in him lies, for preventing of Lo≈øs.

B. his Executors, Admini≈øtrators or A≈ø≈øigns, ≈øhall have and receive the one moiety or half part thereof: and the ≈øaid C.
