(113.) And, for the better and more effectualNeither to take from the Stock without the others con≈øent. proceeding in the ≈øaid affairs and bu≈øine≈ø≈øes before ≈øpecified, to the mutual benefit and advantage of the ≈øaid Parties to the≈øe pre≈øents, their ≈øeveral Executors, Admini≈øtrators and A≈ø≈øigns, either of the ≈øaid Parties for him≈øelf, and for his ≈øeveral Executors and Admini≈øtrators re≈øpectively, doth Covenant, promi≈øe and grant to and with the other of them, his Executors and Admini≈øtrators by the≈øe pre≈øents, in manner and form following: that is to ≈øay, That they, nor either of them, ≈øhall not at any time or times, dating the term of years before ≈øpecified, withdraw, or take any ≈øum or ≈øums of Mony, or any Goods or Merchandizes what≈øoever, out of, or from the ≈øaid Stock of, &c. above-mentioned, or out of, or from any ≈øum or ≈øums of Mony, which ≈øhall be thereunto hereafter added or put, without the con≈øent and agreement of the other of them, his Executors, Admini≈øtrators or A≈ø≈øigns fir≈øt thereunto had and obtained, and that ≈øuch of them, as by ≈øuch con≈øent as is afore≈øaid, ≈øhall at any time or times take any thing out of, or from the ≈øaid Stock, or other ≈øum or ≈øums of Mony thereunto to be added or put, or the proceed thereof, ≈øhall immediately enter into a Book for that purpo≈øe to be kept, the ≈øum or quantity by him or them ≈øo taken out, and the day and year when they took the ≈øame, to the end that the other of the ≈øaid Parties, his Executors, Admini≈øtrators or A≈ø≈øigns, may take notice thereof.

(114.) And al≈øo, that all ≈øuch ≈øum and ≈øumsCharges and lo≈ø≈øes equally to be divided. of Mony as ≈øhall be from time to time hereafter, during the ≈øaid term or ≈øpace of ten years, be laid out or disbur≈øed by the ≈øaid A. B. and C. D. or either of them, in, about or concerning the buying and providing of Coals, or any other fiting, to be ≈øpent onely in and about the Trade and Profe≈ø≈øion afore≈øaid, and that all ≈øuch charges and expences, as ≈øhall be expended or laid forth, in and about the keeping and maintaining
of any Servant or Servants, Hor≈øe or Hor≈øes to be imployed onely about the Art, trade or profe≈ø≈øion afore≈øaid, for the equal benefit and advantage of the ≈øaid Parties to the≈øe pre≈øents, ≈øhall be equally paid, laid out and disbur≈øed, by and between the ≈øaid A. B. and C. D. their Executors, Admini≈øtrators and A≈ø≈øigns, part and part like: And, that lo≈ø≈øes and dammages which ≈øhall happen to come or grow, either by evil or bad Debtors, or by any other ca≈øualty what≈øoever (≈øo as it be not through the wilful negligence or deceit of either of the ≈øaid Parties, their Executors, Admini≈øtrators or A≈ø≈øigns) and all Taxations, Impo≈øitions, and other Duties, to be charged and impo≈øed upon the ≈øaid Parties, or either of them, or either of their Executors or A≈ø≈øigns, by rea≈øon or means of this their joynt trade or dealing; ≈øhall be equally and indifferently born, paid and di≈øcharged, by and between the ≈øaid, A. B. and C. D. their Executors, Admini≈øtrators and A≈ø≈øigns, out of their ≈øeveral parts of the gains and profits, hereafter from time to time to be gotten, by means of u≈øing the Art; Trade or Profe≈ø≈øion afore≈øaid, part and part like.

(115.) And al≈øo, that they the ≈øaid A. B. andTo keep true Books of Account. C. D. and either of them for him≈øelf, his Executors, Admini≈øtrators and A≈ø≈øigns re≈øpectively, doth Covenant, grant and agree, to and with the other o ‚Ä¢ them, his Executors, Admini≈øtrators and A≈ø≈øigns by the≈øe pre≈øents, in manner and form following: that is to ≈øay, That they and either of them, ≈øhall and will, ≈øo near as they may or can‚ñ™ from time to time, during the term of years before-mentioned, keep, or cau≈øe to be kept, ju≈øt and perfect Books of Account and Reckoning, in writing, to the uttermo≈øt of their ≈øeveral knowledge, of all the Payments, Receipts and Debts, to or from them due or owing, and of the Gains, Lo≈ø≈øes, and all other things touching or concerning this their joynt trade or
dealings: which Books ≈øhall be extant from timeFree acce≈øs to them. to time, and at all convenient times, for the Parties afore≈øaid, or their A≈ø≈øigns, to peru≈øe and examine at their and either of their free wills and plea≈øures: And that once in every quarter ofOnce every quarter to account together. a year (upon reque≈øt to be made by one of the ≈øaid Parties to the other of them) during the ≈øaid term: that is to ≈øay, at the Fea≈øts of, &c. or oftner if need ≈øhall be, they the ≈øaid Parties ≈øhall joyn in Reckoning and Account together, and make and deliver up either of them to the other of them, to the be≈øt of their ≈øeveral knowledge, true, plain and perfect Account or Accounts in writing, and concerning the ≈øaid ≈øum or ≈øtock of, &c. and all ≈øuch other ≈øum and ≈øums of Mony, as ≈øhall be thereunto hereafter added or put, and of all other things in joynt trade and dealing between them, and of all Gains and Lo≈ø≈øes ari≈øing thereby, and all Debts to them due or owing, or by or from them due or owing: and of all Receipts, Payments, doings or dealings, in, or concerning their ≈øaid joynt trade or dealing, without any voluntary concealment, withdrawing, or unju≈øt detaining of any of the ≈øaid principal Stock, or of any other ≈øum or ≈øums of Mony thereunto to be put, or of any gains, profit or Commodity, which ≈øhould, or in any wi≈øe ought, to ari≈øe or come to the equal u≈øes of the ≈øaid Parties, by the true intent and meaning of the≈øe pre≈øents.

(116.) And, that upon every ≈øuch Account and Accounts, ≈øo from time to time, in form afore≈øaid,The cleer Gains to be divided upon the account. to be made and pa≈ø≈øed, all the clear gains, profit and increa≈øe which ≈øhall be found upon the foot of any ≈øuch Account or Accounts, ≈øhall be immediately ≈øhared, parted and divided in equal halves between the ≈øaid Parties, their Executors, Admini≈øtrators and A≈ø≈øigns: that is to ≈øay, The ≈øaid A. B. his Executors, Admini≈øtrators or A≈ø≈øigns, ≈øhall have and receive the one moiety, or half part thereof, and the ≈øaid C. D. his Executors,
Admini≈øtrators or A≈ø≈øigns, ≈øhall have and receive the other moiety or half part thereof.

(117.) And it is further Covenanted and agreed,No advantage by Survivor. by and between the ≈øaid A. B. and C. D. And either of them doth ≈øeverally and re≈øpectively Covenant, grant and agree, for him≈øelf, his Executors, Admini≈øtrators and A≈ø≈øigns, to and with the other of them, his Executors, Admini≈øtrators and A≈ø≈øigns by the≈øe pre≈øents, That if it ≈øhall fortune either of the ≈øaid Parties to die, or depart this life, during the term of years above-≈øpecified, before any ≈øeparation or divi≈øion ≈øhall be made between them, of their ≈øaid joynt dealings (the other of them ≈øurviving) that in ≈øuch ca≈øe no advantage by the Survivor of the ≈øaid Parties, his Executors or Admini≈øtrators, in right or in re≈øpect of his Survivor≈øhip ≈øhall hold or take place, or be by him or them taken, challenged or demanded, but that ≈øuch part and portion of, in, and to the ≈øaid principal Stock, and the gains and increa≈øe thereof, which is, or ≈øhall be due or belonging to ≈øuch of the ≈øaid Parties ≈øo decea≈øing, at the time of his death, ≈øhall come and be payed to the Executors, Admini≈øtrators or A≈ø≈øigns of the ≈øaid decea≈øed Party, in ≈øuch like, and ≈øo large, ample and beneficial manner and form, as the ≈øame ought to have grown due, or been payed or ≈øatisfied, unto the ≈øaid decea≈øed Party him≈øelf, if he had been living, at the time of the ≈øurcea≈øing or determination of the ≈øaid Copartner≈øhip.

(118.) And the ≈øaid C. D. for him≈øelf, hisTo be faithful. Executors and Admini≈øtrators, doth Covenant and grant to and with the ≈øaid A. B. his Executors, Admini≈øtrators and A≈ø≈øigns by the≈øe pre≈øents, in manner and form following: that is to ≈øay: That he the ≈øaid C. D. ≈øhall and will at all times hereafter, during the term of years before ≈øpecified, or continuance of this Copartner≈øhip, deal uprightly, truly and faithfully with the ≈øaid
A. B. his Executors; Admini≈øtrators or A≈ø≈øigns in all re≈øpects, touching and concerning the u≈øing and exerci≈øing of the Art, Trade or Profe≈ø≈øion afore≈øaid.

(119.) And further, that he the ≈øaid C. D. Not to take up, or lend upon Credit without the others con≈øent. ≈øhall not at any time or times hereafter, during the term of years before-≈øpecified; or continuance of this Copartner≈øhip, take up upon Credit, or for Time, any Goods, Wares or Merchandizes to be u≈øed or imployed in, or about the ≈øaid Art, Trade, or Profe≈ø≈øion of a Pewterer, without the con≈øent and agreement of the ≈øaid A. B. his Executors, Admini≈øtrators and A≈ø≈øigns, fir≈øt had and obtained in that behalf: Neither that he the ≈øaid C. D. or his A≈ø≈øigns, ≈øhall at any time or times hereafter, during the term of years afore≈øaid, or continuance of this Copartner≈øhip, lend or credit out to any per≈øon or per≈øons what≈øoever, any Wares, Goods or Merchandizes, which ≈øhall belong or be incident to the ≈øaid Art, Trade, or Profe≈ø≈øion of a Pewterer, and ≈øhall be belonging to their ≈øaid joynt dealings, without the like con≈øent and agreement of the ≈øaid A. B. his Executors, Admini≈øtrators and A≈ø≈øigns fir≈øt had and obtained in that behalf.

(120.) And furthermore, that he the ≈øaid C. The final Accompt. ment. Stairs. the ≈øaid Cellar, out of the ≈øtreet, with good and ≈øub≈øtantial Iron-bars to the ≈øame Windows: The ≈øaid Windows, to be of ≈øuch largene≈øs and form as the ≈øaid A. F. forTime of fini≈øhing the Hou≈øe. them≈øelves and either of them, their and either of their Executors, Admini≈øtrators and A≈ø≈øigns, do by the≈øe pre≈øents Covenant, promi≈øe and grant, to and with the ≈øaid A. ∆≤pon a Fine to be levied, Sect. 1, 2, 3. ∆≤pon a Fine already levied, Sect. 4. ∆≤pon a Recovery to be had, Sect. 5, 6, 12. ∆≤pon a Recovery already had, Sect. 7, 8, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14. A Relea≈øe of Errors in the Recovery, Sect. 9.
∆≤pon a Fine and Recovery to be had, the Fine being of one thing, the Recovery of another, Sect. 15, 16. The like upon Fine and Recovery already had, Sect. 17.
∆≤pon a Fine, Recovery, and other Conveyances to be had, Sect. 18. ∆≤pon a Feoffment pa≈øt and executed, Sect. 20, 24. ∆≤pon a Covenant to ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed, Sect. 21. ∆≤pon a Bargain and Sale, and Grant of the Rever≈øion, Sect. 22.
Chap. 6. The ≈øeveral forms of indor≈øing Livery and Attornment, Sect. 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7. Form of Attornment by Deed, Sect. 8.

Chap. 7. The ≈øeveral forms of limitation of ∆≤≈øes.
For Life: For Lives of Husband and Wife, and longer liver, Sect. 1.
To Husband for life, after to Wife for life for a Joynture, Sect. 2. With Provi≈øo to make the limitation to her void upon her claim of other Lands, Sect. 3. ∆≤pon parting with her E≈øtate, Sect. 4. For years. ∆≤≈øe for years determinable upon life, Sect. 5. ∆≤≈øe for years to pay Daughters Portions, Sect. 15.
In Tayl, to 1, 2, 3, &c. Sons, in remainder after an E≈øtate for life, remainder to all other Sons in Tayl, according to ≈øeigniority, &c. Sect. 6. Another to Sons already born, by name, in Tayl, with like remainder, Sect. 7. To the Father for life, remainder to Son for life, remainder to Sons Wife for life, in ≈øatisfaction of Dower, ‚ñ™the remainder to their 1, 2, 3, &c. Sons in Tayl, remainder to the ≈øeveral Sons of the Grandfather in Tayl, remainder to the Heirs of the Body of the Grandfather, remainder to Grandfathers right Heirs, with a Provi≈øo to pre≈øerve E≈øtates in Tayl to Children, en ventre ≈øa mere, Sect. 8, 9. To the u≈øe of A. B. and Heirs Males of his Body, remainder to C. B. his Brother, and Heirs Males of his Body, with like remainders to his other Brothers, remainder to the right Heirs of A. B. Sect. 10. Other limitations in Tayl, with remainder to the Heirs Males of the Body of Feoffors Father, remainder to the Heirs Males of the Body of Feoffors Grandfather, remainder to the right Heirs of the Feoffor, Sect. 11. An ∆≤≈øe to the Heirs of the Body of the Wife by the Husband begotten, with remainder over to the Husband, Sect. 13.
In Fee determinable upon a Marriage had, Sect. 12.
An ∆≤≈øe limited to one, until the Heir in Tail come to full age, in ca≈øe the Father die while he is within age, and after to the Heir, Sect. 13. Another with direction for di≈øpo≈øing the Profits in the mean time, Sect. 14.
The form of a limitation to pre≈øerve contingent ∆≤≈øes, in ca≈øe the particular E≈øtate determine before they come in E≈ø≈øe, Sect. 15. Contingent ∆≤≈øes, Sect. 16.

Chap. 8. Power given to ce≈øtuy que U≈øe for life, to make Joyntures, Lea≈øes, &c.
To make Joyntures to future Wives, Sect. 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. To ≈øettle Lands in certain upon a future Wife for life, re≈øerving a Rent, Sect. 7. The like of a third part, without Re≈øervation, Sect. 8. Provi≈øion made for future Wives, by way of limitation of ∆≤≈øe, Sect. 9.
To make Lea≈øes for lives, or years determinable upon lives, or for 21 years, with or without re≈øervation of Rent, Sect. 10. To make Lea≈øes for ≈øuch Terms, and under ≈øuch Rent as Le≈ø≈øor plea≈øeth, Sect. 15. For ce≈øtuy que U≈øe for life, or his I≈ø≈øue-male to make Lea≈øes, ≈øo as they be not without impeachment of wa≈øte, and that the pre≈øent Rent be re≈øerved, Sect. 11. Like power for them to make Joyntures, Sect. 12. To Lea≈øe the Lands ≈øetled on the Wife for a Joynture, at a Rent mentioned in the Schedule, the Wife being made party, Sect. 13. Another to make Lea≈øes, ≈øo as Wife be party, Sect. 14, 16. To make Lea≈øes at the ancient Rents, chargable neverthele≈øs with the Rents before in the Deed limited, Sect. 17. Power to two ce≈øtuy que U≈øes for life, to make Lea≈øes ≈øucce≈ø≈øively, Sect. 19. A ∆≤≈øe limited briefly to ≈øuch per≈øons, to whom ce≈øtuy que U≈øe for life ≈øhall make Lea≈øes, Sect. 20, 21.

Chap. 9. Rents, Annuities and Portions, a≈ø≈øured out of the limitation of ∆≤≈øes.
An Annuity for charitable ∆≤≈øes, Sect. 1, 2. Another of a Rent for life, with Clau≈øe of Di≈øtre≈øs, and a limitation of the Land unto the Party, upon failer of payment of the Rent, Sect. 3, 4, 5, 6, 7. A limitation of the Land to ≈øeveral ∆≤≈øes, chargable with the Rents after mentioned, and after, the Rents are appointed with power to di≈øtrain, Sect. 8, 9.
Portions for Daughters to be rai≈øed out of Lea≈øes made by ce≈øtuy que U≈øe for life, according to power given him, Sect. 10. A ∆≤≈øe for years limited to Cognizees to pay Portions, with directions over if Daughters die, Sect. 11, 12, 19. Money yearly to be allowed to the Daughters until Portions paid, Sect. 13. A limitation for years to be void if Feoffor die without Daughters, or after Portions paid, Sect. 14, 15. A limitation to Daughters (for want of I≈ø≈øue-male) to be void upon Portions paid, or ≈øecured by him in the next remainder, Sect. 16, 17. Daughters Portions to be rai≈øed out of a Rent-Charge, with ce≈øtuy que U≈øe for life, hath power given him to grant, Sect. 18, 19, 20, 21.

Chap. 10. Provi≈øion taken for payment of Debts, Legacies, &c. in the limitation of ∆≤≈øes.
A limitation for years to the Cognizees, for payment of Cognizors Debts, di≈øcharge of Sureties, payment of Annuities to Servants, and then to ≈øurrender the E≈øtate, Sect. 1. A limitation to Cognizees and their Heirs, for payment of Cognizors Debts (by ≈øale) and di≈øcharge of Sureties, and to re≈øtore the overplus, &c. but if next Heir pay the Debts, &c. within a year, then the Cognizees to convey to him, Sect. ‚Ä¢ . To make ≈øale and pay Debts mentioned in a Schedule, with direction for the overplus, and Cognizor to enjoy until
≈øale, Sect. 3. A limitation after Cognizors death, to Cognizors Executors for years to pay Debts, &c. Sect. 4. For performance of Cognizors Will, Sect. 5. A ∆≤≈øe limited to ≈øuch per≈øons as Cognizor ≈øhall appoint to pay a ≈øum in certain, Sect. 6.

Chap. 11. The form of alteration of ∆≤≈øes upon Acts done.
∆≤pon ≈øetling other Lands on Cognizors Wife, the ∆≤≈øe limited to her to cea≈øe, with a limitation over, S. 2. A ∆≤≈øe altered and limited to a per≈øon, to whom a Rent is appointed upon default of payment, S. 3, 4, 5. A ∆≤≈øe made void, and a limitation over, if ce≈øtuy que U≈øe marry without Fathers con≈øent, S. 6, 7, 8. A limitation to the Wife to cea≈øe, and a limitation‚ñ™ over, upon her claiming of Dower, S. 9, 10. A ∆≤≈øe altered upon Non-payment of a ≈øum in gro≈øs, S. 11, 12, 13, 14, 15. To alter a ∆≤≈øe upon payment back of a Marriage-Portion, in ca≈øe the Marriage take none effect, S. 16.

Chap. 12. Power given to Revoke ∆≤≈øes, and limit new. S. 1, 2, 3, 4. To Revoke ∆≤≈øes, with exception of Lea≈øes to be made by force of a power given in the ≈øame Deed, S. 5, 9. To Revoke old ∆≤≈øes and limit new, as to particular per≈øons, S. 6, 7. Another, as to one particular Mannor, S. 10. To Revoke old ∆≤≈øes and limit new, with con≈øent of Cognizees, S. 8.

Chap. 13. The forms of Deeds of Revocation, and limitation of new ∆≤≈øes.
A ≈øhort form, S. 1. Another with recital of the power of Revocation, S. 2, 3. Another with a Feoffment added, S. 4. Another of a ∆≤≈øe ≈øetled by Covenant to ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed, S. 5. Another pur≈øuant to power given upon having of I≈ø≈øue, S. 6.

Chap. 14. The ≈øeveral forms of ≈øettlements of E≈øtates.
By Covenant to levy a Fine, and declaration of ∆≤≈øes, with power to make Joyntures, grant Rents, and make Lea≈øes, S. 1, 2, 3, 4, 5. Another by ∆≤≈øes declared upon a Fine and Recovery, with provi≈øion for payment of Debts, S. 6. Another by declaration of ∆≤≈øes of a Recovery, as to ≈øeveral Mannors ≈øeverally, S. 7, 8. The ∆≤≈øe of a Recovery for life, with remainders over in Tail, S. 9. ∆≤≈øe of a Mannor in Tru≈øt to be ≈øold, and Appointment for the di≈øpo≈øition of the money, S. 10. Provi≈øo to make void a particular ∆≤≈øe, upon payment of money, and a limitation over, S. 11. Another to give power to make Lea≈øes of a particular Mannor to pay Portions, S. 13.

Chap. 15. The forms of ≈øeveral Covenants, u≈øed upon ≈øettlements of E≈øtates to ∆≤≈øes.
To ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed to the ∆≤≈øes before-mentioned, in ca≈øe the Conveyance prove deficient, S. 1, 2. That he is owner and hath power to ≈øettle, S. 3, 4, 5. That the thing is free from incumbrances, S. 6, 7, 8. To enjoy, S. 9, 10. Not to do any Act to impeach the ≈øettlement, S. 11. For further A≈ø≈øurance, S. 12, 13. For ≈øettlement of Lands to be purcha≈øed, S. 14. To permit Lands to de≈øcend, S. 15.

Chap. 16. The ≈øeveral forms of Joyntures, before and after Marriage.
Before Marriage, mutual Covenants that each party ≈øhall marry the other, S. 1. A Joynture by way of Covenant to ≈øtand ≈øei≈øed to ∆≤≈øes, S. 2. Another by Covenant to levy a Fine to ∆≤≈øes, S. 3. ∆≤≈øes upon a Fine, to the end that the young pair ≈øhall receive a Rent, during Fathers life, S. 4. And a limitation of a ∆≤≈øe after, as
to the Mannors, Lands, &c. S. 5. With a Provi≈øo to cea≈øe a limitation to Daughters, upon Portions paid, S. 6. Another upon Marriage with a Widow, with ≈øeveral Covenants relating to the Widows Children, and power given to her to make a Will, S. 7, 8. 9, 10, 11, 12. A Rent limited to the intended Wife in ≈øatisfaction of Dower, with a limitation over of the u≈øe of the Lands, S. 19, 20.
After Marriage, by Covenant to levy a Fine to the u≈øe of Husband for life, after of the Wife for life in ≈øatisfaction of Dower, with remainders in Tail, and a Covenant to alter the ∆≤≈øe upon her claim of Dower, S. 13, 14. Another by way of Feoffment to ∆≤≈øes, as to ≈øeveral Mannors ≈øeverally, with a limitation for rai≈øing of Portions, S. 15, 16, 17. A Provi≈øo to cea≈øe the limitation to the Wife, as to part, if ≈øhe marry again, S. 18.

Chap. 17. Containing ≈øeveral Covenants u≈øed upon Marriages and Joyntures made.
To pay the Marriage-Portion, S. 1. To pay a ≈øum upon refu≈øal of the Marriage, S. 2. To maintain the young pair, S. 3. To give or leave a ≈øum by Will to them, S. 4. To do further Acts to ratifie Covenants, S. 5. To permit the Wife to make a Will, S. 3, 6, 7. If the Lands ≈øetled in Joynture fail of the value, then the Hu≈øbands Executors to make it up, S. 8. To make ≈øatisfaction for what ≈øhall be evicted, S. 9. To repay part of the Portion if the Wife die within three years, without I≈ø≈øue, S. 10.

Chap. 18. Containing general words commonly u≈øed for pa≈ø≈øing Mannors, Lands, &c.
For a Mannor, S. 1. A Mannor and Advow≈øon, S. 2. A
Me≈ø≈øuage and Lands, S. 3. A Me≈ø≈øuage in London, S. 4. An Inn, S. 5. A Brew-hou≈øe, S. 6. A Watergri≈øt Miln, S. 7, 8. A Prebend, S. 9. A Rectory, S. 10.

Another, as to particular ∆≤≈øes, ch. 12. ≈ø. 6. 7 The form of a ≈øhort Deed of Revocation, ch. 13. ≈ø. 1 Another, with recital of the Power of Revocation, ch 13. ≈ø. 2, 3. Another, with a Feoffment added, ≈øect. 4: Another, of ∆≤≈øes ≈øetled by Covenant to stand ≈øeized, ch. 13. ≈ø. 5. That he ≈øhall permit him in remainder to enjoy the Land, until Portions paid to Sons and Daughters by him in Remainder; but after default to enter, and rai≈øe the Portions, and then to ≈øurrender his Estate, ch. 9. ≈ø. 19, 20. A limitation for years to Executors in Trust, to pay Debts and Legacies, ch. 10. ≈ø. 4. To perform a Will, ≈øect. 5, 6. To ≈øell and di≈øpo≈øe the Mony as it's appointed, ch. 14. ≈øect 10.

U≈øes: The forms of introducing ∆≤≈øes upon Fines, Recoveries, &c. vide the other Table in chap 5. The ≈øeveral forms of limitation of ∆≤≈øes. See the other Table in chap. 7. That Feoffees and Cognizees ≈øhall stand ≈øeized to the u≈øe of ≈øuch Per≈øons, in whom an Estate for life ≈øhall be ≈øetled by Ce≈øtuy que u≈øe for life, according to power to him given, and after to other u≈øes, chap. 8. ≈øect. 1, 2, 3, 4, 5. As to ≈øeveral Mannors, ≈øeveral ∆≤≈øes ch. 14 ≈øect 6. A ∆≤≈øe limited to ≈øuch Per≈øons to whom Lea≈øes ≈øhall be made,
according to power given by the Deed, Ch. 8. Sect 20, 21. Ch. 9. S. 10. Ch. 14. Sect. 5 A ∆≤≈øe limited, to the end a Rent may be paid, with clau≈øe of Distre≈øs, and a Limitation over of the ∆≤≈øe of the Land, chargable with the Rent, Ch. 9. S. 3, 4, 5, 6. ∆≤≈øe of the Land to ≈øeveral per≈øons, chargable notwithstanding with the Rents after mentioned, C 9‚ñ™ S. 8, 9. Ch. 14. S. 2, 5.

A ∆≤≈øe changed upon non payment of an Annuity, Ch. 9. S 2, 3. A ∆≤≈øe limited to Daughters, in default of Heirs Males to cea≈øe, upon payment of their Portions by him in remainder, and the ∆≤≈øe then is limited to him, Ch. 9. S. 16, 17. div.head: Arcana Clericalia: Or, THE MYSTERIES OF CLERKSHIP.
CAP. I. What a FINE is.
div.p:
A FINE is that which is accounted of all kind of A≈ø≈øurances the highe≈øt and mo≈øt forcible, and although it be but fictio Juris, yet it is called a Fine quia finem litibus imponit, and is al≈øo ≈øaid to be exceptio peremptoria, and therefore not onely e≈øteemed A micab ‚Ä¢ lis compo≈øitio but finalis concordia, the latter of which it is de≈øervedly ≈øaid to be, quia finem ponit negotio, adeo ut neutra pars litigantium ab eo de cetero po≈ø≈øit recedere. It is an In≈øtrument or A≈ø≈øurance containing a final Agreement (commonly made by the con≈øent of per≈øons, ≈øometimes by force of a Suite in Law upon ≈øome Covenant for the levying thereof) concerning Lands, Tenements, Hereditaments, Rent, or other things, wherein the
Kings Licence mu≈øt be duly had and obtained, It mu≈øt be acknowledged by the Cognizor, Deforceant, or he that parts with his right in the ‚Ä¢ ands contained in the Fine, upon a writ of Covenant (mo≈øt commonly, but ≈øometimes upon a) Quid juris clamat, per quae ≈øervicia, de rationabilibus divi≈øis, de Recto patens, de Recto clau≈øum, warantia Cha ‚Ä¢ tae, &c. as the ca≈øe requires, before the Iu≈øtices of the Common Pleas, or ≈øuch other per≈øons thereunto authorized by Commi≈ø≈øion out of Chancery, and la≈øtly, it mu≈øt be ingro≈ø≈øed upon Record in the ≈øame Court, there to remain for ever for the ending and compo≈øing of all differences and controver≈øies as well between the parties and privies to the ≈øame, as all ≈øtrangers not claiming in due time. Although a Fine is now become a formal A≈ø≈øurance of common u≈øe from the re≈øult of a feigned difference, yet anciently it was the compo≈øure of a real controver≈øie, and the end of a Suite indeed. For after the parties had contended by ≈øuite in law about the thing in que≈øtion, by agreement a fine was levyed of it, and ≈øo the difference was ended. This of all other is e≈øteemed the be≈øt A≈ø≈øurance, and is much of the nature of a Feoffment with Livery and Sei≈øin executed thereupon, but of greater efficacy, and therefore called a Feoffment upon Record. By this Lands may be conveyed in Fee-≈øimple, Fee-tayl for life, or for years, and rent thereby al≈øo re≈øerved, And la≈øtly to ≈øum up all in the words of the Sages of the Law‚ÄîThere neither is, nor can be provided by the Laws of the Land, any greater or more noble Security, by which any per≈øon may make his E≈øtate more ≈øecure, or produce a Te≈øtimony of the highe≈øt Nature for confirmation of his E≈øtate, then a Fine levyed in the Kings Court upon Record: which is therefore called a Fine, becau≈øe it ought to be the Complement, and end of all proceedings and differences.

div.head: CAP. II. Of the ≈øeveral kinds of a Fine.
div.p: OF Fines there be four kinds. The fir≈øt whereof is called a Fine ≈øur Cognizance de droit come ceo que il ad de ≈øon done. which is ≈øingle, and called al≈øo a Fine ≈øur Relea≈øe. The ≈øecond is a Fine ≈øur Cognizance de droit come ceo que il ad de ≈øon done, which is double, and properly called a Fine ≈øur done grant & render. The third is called a Fine ≈øur Cognizance de droit tantum, which is ≈øometimes ≈øingle, ≈øometimes with Grant, and then it is called a Fine ≈øur done grant. And the fourth a Fine ≈øur conce≈ø≈øit.

A Fine ≈øur Cognizance de droit come ceo que A Fine ≈øur Cognizance de droit come ceo, &c. what it is? il ad de ≈øon done is the be≈øt, mo≈øt principal, and ≈øure≈øt of all kind of Fines, by which an E≈øtate pa≈ø≈øeth ab≈øolutely to the Cognizee, without rendring any thing back again to the Cognizor; and therefore is ≈øaid to be ≈øingle. It is levyed with Proclamations according to the form of the Statute 4 H. 7. Cap. 24. It is ≈øaid to be executed, viz. ≈øuch a Fine whereby the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion in Law of the lands contained therein is immediately transferred to, and v ‚Ä¢ ≈øted in the Cognizee without the help of a writ of habere facias ≈øei≈øinam; ≈øo that he may enter: for that the E≈øtate is thereby (in law) in the Cognizee, that is to ≈øay, to ≈øuch u≈øes as are declared in the deed leading the u≈øe of the Fine; for take this for a maxime, That unle≈øs it be declared by deed (or otherwi≈øe) to what u≈øe the Fine was levyed, the Fine ≈øhall be and inure to the u≈øe of the Cognizor that levyed the Fine.

A Fine ≈øur done grant & render, is that which isA Fine ≈øur done grant & render, what? called a double Fine, being in a manner two Fines (that is to ≈øay, A Fine ≈øur Cognizance de droit come ceo, &c. and a Fine ≈øur Conce≈ø≈øit) form'd into one, whereby the Cognizee (after Relea≈øe and warranty made to him by the Cognizor of the lands contained therein) doth grant and render back to the
Cognizor the lands, &c. or ≈øome part thereof, and many times limitting thereby Remainders to per≈øons that are Strangers, and not named in the writ of Covenant. This fine is partly executed, partly executory, and hath Proclamations, and is (quoad partem priorem) ab≈øolutely of the ≈øame Nature with a Fine ≈øur Cognizance de droit come ceo, &c. but as to the ≈øecond part containing a Grant and render (as afore≈øaid) it is taken in law to be rather a private Conveyance or Charter, then to have the force of a Fine, which (as we have before expre≈ø≈øed) is declared to be a Feoffment upon Record. With this agrees the Lord Cooks expo≈øition in 5. Rep. fo. 38. where ≈øpeaking of a Fine with Render he hath the≈øe words. The Cognizance of a Fine, and a Grant and render therein; ≈øhall be expounded and taken as a Charter, or other Conveyance between party and party, and not as a Writ or Iudgment upon Record.

A Fine ≈øur Cognizance de droit tantum, ove Fine ≈øur done grant, what? grant (which is al≈øo called a Fine ≈øur done grant) is levyed without Proclamations, executory, and much of the Nature of a Fine ≈øur Conce≈ø≈øit, and is u≈øed commonly by Tenant for life to make a ≈øurrender of the Lands contained in it, to him or them that have the Rever≈øion or Remainder thereof, and ≈øo you will find it u≈øed Chap. 10. Sect. 1. and 5. of this Treati≈øe. And ≈øometimes it is expre≈ø≈øed by ≈øuch Fine, that the particular E≈øtate is in another, and that the Cognizor willeth that the other ≈øhall have the Rever≈øion, or that the land ≈øhall remain to the other after the particular E≈øtate ≈øpent. We≈øt. Symb. part. 2. Dyer 216. Plowd. 265. Coke 3. 86. and 7. 12. Crooke 1. la≈øt publi≈øhed fo. 693.

A Fine ≈øur Conce≈ø≈øit, is where the Cognizor isFine ≈øur Conce≈ø≈øit, what? ≈øei≈øed of the Lands contained therein, and the Cognizee hath no Freehold therein, but it pa≈ø≈øeth by the Fine, it is without proclamations and executory, for the Cognizee or Cognizees therein mu≈øt enter, and have a writ of habere facias ≈øei≈øinam, according to their ≈øeveral ca≈øes, for the obtaining of the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, if the parties at the time of levying ≈øuch
Fine ≈øur Conce≈ø≈øit be not in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the thing granted, but if they be in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion at ≈øuch time, there needs not any ≈øuch Writ or any Execution of the ≈øaid Fine to put them into po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion; for then the Fine will enure by way of Extingui≈øhment of Right, and doth not alter the E≈øtate or right of the Cognizee, however perchance it may better it.

div.head: CAP. III. Of the parts of a Fine.
div.p: THe parts of a Fine are five, viz. The writ of Covenant. 2. The Compo≈øition, or the Kings licence to alienate. 3. The Concord. 4. The Note of the Fine. 5. The foot of the Fine. And if it be a Fine ≈øur Cognizance de droit come ceo, &c. it is requi≈øite that a ≈øixth be added, viz. Proclamations, as a nece≈ø≈øary adjunct thereunto.

(1) The writ of Covenant is the original writWrit of Covenant. taken out by the Cognizee or Cognizees again≈øt the Cognizor or Cognizors to the Fine: for without ‚Ä¢ his a Fine cannot be levyed: And a Fine may be levyed upon any writ of Right, or other writ whereby Land is demanded or may be recovered.
(2) The Compo≈øition or Kings Licence to alienate,Compo≈øition. for which the „Äà‚óä„Äâ hath a Fine or ≈øum of mony, which is called the Kings Silver, and is paid in when the Land repo≈øeth.

(3) The Concord, or Agreement between theConcord. parties that intend the levying of the Fine, wherein is declared how and in what manner the things contained in the writ ≈øhall pa≈øs; and as the writ of Covenant is the foundation, ≈øo this is the ≈øub≈øtance of the Fine. For if the Kings Fine be entered and indor≈øed upon the writ of Covenant by the Clerk of the Kings Silver, although the Cognizor dye before the Fine comes to the Chirographer, yet is the
Fine good, for the Note, and foot of the Fine, are but Ab≈øtracts taken out of this by the Chirographer.

(4) The Note of the Fine, which is an Ab≈øtractNote of the Fine. taken out of the writ of Covenant, and Concord, by the Chirographer before it be ingro≈ø≈øed, and begins thus, ≈ø≈ø. Inter A. B. quer. &. C. D. deforcientem.

(5) The foot of the Fine includeth the wholeFoot of the Fine. Fine, the parties to the ≈øame, the thing granted, the day year and place, and before whom the Concord was made; and this is called the foot becau≈øe it is the la≈øt part of the Fine. And when this is done the Fine is ingro≈ø≈øed of Record, and the Indentures made by the Chirographer, and delivered to the party to whom the Cognizance is made, and then the Fine is ≈øaid to be ingro≈ø≈øed.

The Proclamations made upon a Fine, which although they be not the e≈ø≈øential parts of a Fine, yet as is ≈øaid before are requi≈øite to a Fine ≈øur Cognizance de droit come ceo, &c. for they do make a Bar according to what doth pa≈øs.

div.head: CAP. IV. Who may be Cognizors and Cognizees in Fines, and by what names they may give and take in a Fine.
div.p:
SVch per≈øons Male or Female, or bodies ≈øole orWho may be Cognizors in Fines. Corporate that are capable of granting by deed may be Cognizors in Fines. And ≈øo an Infant, Feme covert, an Ideot, mad or Lunatick per≈øon, one non ≈øane memorie, or that hath a Lethargy, or a doting old per≈øon that wants di≈øcretion, a man that is drunk, or one born blind, deaf, and dumb, a Ba≈øtard, an out-lawed per≈øon, or one Attainted of Trea≈øon, or Felony, or per≈øons that are compelled thereto by threats and Menaces to lo≈øe their lives, or members, or to ≈øuffer Impri≈øonment:
and a Fine levyed by them may be good. But the Iudges or Commi≈ø≈øioners before whom Fines are to be levyed by ≈øuch per≈øons, ought not to admit ≈øuch unfit per≈øons to acknowledge Fines, as Madmen, Lunaticks, Ideots, doting per≈øons, men that have the Lethargy, or are drunk, Infants, Fe ‚Ä¢ e Coverts, and ≈øuch as are forced to it by threats or Impri≈øonment, neither ought ≈øuch as are born blind, deaf, and dumb, per≈øons attainted of Trea≈øon or Felony, and ≈øuch like to be received to levy Fines. But if any of the≈øe be admitted Cognizor in a Fine, and ≈øuch Fine be thereupon levyed in due form of law, The Fine in mo≈øt ca≈øes will be good and unavoidable. Coke 12. 124. Lit. Sect. 731. fieri non debet, ≈øed factum valet.

A Fine may al≈øo be levyed by a Mayor and Commonalty, and ≈øuch other Corporations Civil, and bodies Politick as have an ab≈øolute E≈øtate in their po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions belonging to their Corporations, if it be done together, and by the joynt con≈øent of the body Corporate; For no one of the Corporation, no not the head of the Corporation by him≈øelf, nor any of the Members (though the greate≈øt part of them con≈øent thereto) without the general con≈øent of the whole Corporation, may Levy a Fine, for that ≈øhall not be good. Corporations Spiritual, as Bi≈øhops, Deans and Chapters, Heads and Fellows of Colleges, and the like, are forbidden, and re≈øtrained by divers Acts of Parliament from levying any Fine of their lands belonging to them at this day: but of the lands ≈øuch per≈øons have in their own Right, they may levy Fines as other per≈øons may do.
A Fine levyed by one Ioyntenant, Tenant in Common or Partner of Lands ≈øo held by him, to a Stranger, another Ioyntenant, Tenant in Common or Partner, will be good.

And la≈øtly take this general Caution concerning Cognizors in Fines, That they mu≈øt be ≈øuch, and have ≈øuch an E≈øtate in the Lands intended to be granted by Fine, as they are not prohibited by any Law to levy the Fine, otherwi≈øe the Fine will be void. And hence it is, That Bi≈øhops, Deans and
Chapters, Prebends, Par≈øons, Vicars, and the like may not levy a Fine of any Eccle≈øia≈øtical Lands in which they have any E≈øtate of Freehold in right of their Churches, Hou≈øes, &c. for if they do, it will be void after their lives, Coke 11. 78. Plowd. 575. 538. 375. 21 Edw. 4. 13. And hence it is that he that hath an E≈øtate Tayl of the Kings gift of provi≈øion may not levy a good Fine of it to bind the King, or the I≈ø≈øue in Tayl, by 32 H. 8. Cap. 28. And that a Fine levyed by the heir that is an Intruder upon the Kings po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, is void, 1 H. 7. 5. 24 Edw. 3. 65. And hence it is that he that hath an E≈øtate in Fee-≈øimple of lands in the Right of his wife, may not levy a Fine thereof without her, and if he do, ≈øhe or her heirs, or other per≈øon to whom the right may come, may avoid it after her death. 32 H. 8. Cap. 28. 12 Edw. 4. 14. Coke 6. 55. Brooke Fines 121.

Concerning Cognizees in Fines, you are toW ‚Ä¢ o may be Cognizees in Fines. know, That any per≈øon that is capable of being a good Grantee in a Deed, may be a good Cognizee in a Fine, and may thereby have and take the thing granted by it. And ≈øo any man or woman, Sole or Covert, of full age, or under age, any mad or Lunatick per≈øon, Ideot, or man de non ≈øane memorie, any per≈øon in, or out of pri≈øon, or beyond Sea, any per≈øon attainted of Felony or Trea≈øon, or outlawed in a per≈øonal Action, a Ba≈øtard, a Clerk convict, an Alien, any one of the≈øe may be a Cognizee, and take by a Fine as well as by a Deed. And a Fine levyed to any ≈øuch per≈øon is good. 50 Edw. 3. 9. 3 H. 6. 42. 24 Edw. 3. 62.

So Corporations Spiritual and Temporal, Civil or Corporal, may be Cognizees in Fines, and Fines levyed to them will be good. But before the Ingro≈ø≈øing of ≈øuch a Fine, there goeth alwaies a Writ to the Iu≈øtices of Common Pleas, Quod permittunt Finem illum levari.

Note that a Fine ≈øur Cognizance de droit come ceo, &c. may not be levyed to any per≈øon, but one that is party to the writ of Covenant. Except the Cognizee be a Demandant in a writ of Entry;
And ≈øo a Fine levyed by the Demandant to the Vouchee (who is ≈øuppo≈øed by the Law to be Tenant to the land) or from the Vouchee to the Demandant is good, and yet they are not Parties to the Writ. But a Fine levyed by the Vouchee to a Stranger is void. Coke 3. 29. 7 Edw. 4. 13.

Care mu≈øt be taken in Fines that Cognizors andBy what names Cognizors and Cognizees may give and take in a Fine. Cognizees mu≈øt be named in Fines by their right names of Bapti≈øm, and Surname: except they be Kings, Princes, Dukes, Marque≈ø≈øes, Earls, Vi≈øcounts, or Barons, which are admitted without any ≈øurname, as Jacobus Rex Angliae, Carolus Princeps Walliae, Johannes Dux Lanca≈øtr. &c. But for Knights, E≈øquires, and Gentlemen (which be names of Wor≈øhip, and Honour) their Chri≈øtian name, and Sur-name are alwaies expre≈ø≈øed, together with their Additions. And as for the Additions of Bi≈øhop, Dean, Par≈øon, &c. they are admitted in Fines rather out of Courte≈øie, then nece≈ø≈øity, for the Fine may be good without them. Brownlow 1. part. 30. 7 H. 4. 22. 1. A≈ø≈ø. pl. 11. 14 H. 6. 15. 21 Edw. 4. 8. 1. A≈ø≈ø. pl. 11. But if there be two of one name it is be≈øt to di≈øtingui≈øh them by Seniori, Juniori, or the like. Brownlow 1. part. 30. So if it be a Corporation or Fraternity to be named in the Fine care mu≈øt be had, that it be done by the very true name of the Corporation, as it is named in the Charter and Foundation of it. 11 H. 4 44. 14 H. 4. 20. 7 H. 6. 27. 37 H. 6. 29.

div.head: CAP. V. Of what things Fines may be levyed, and ‚Ä¢ by what Names, and how the Parcels are to be placed therein.
div.p:
A Fine may be levyed of all things whereof aOf what things Fines may be levyed. Precipe quod reddat lyeth, or of which a writ of Entry may be brought. It will be good of all things Eccle≈øia≈øtical or Temporal, that are inheritable, and in E≈ø≈øe at the time of the levying of the Fine. So a Fine may be levyed of an Honour, Mannor, I≈øland, Barony, Ca≈øtle, Me≈ø≈øuage, Cottage, Mill, Toft, Curtilage, Dov ‚Ä¢
hou≈øe, Garden, Land, Meadow, Pa≈øture, Wood, Vnder-wood, Chappel, River, Par≈øonage, Rectory, Advow≈øon, Vicaridge, Tythes impropriate, ‚Ä¢ ≈øtovers, Foldage, Corrody, Office, Fi≈øhing, Warren, Fair, Mine, View of Frank-pledge, Waif, Stray, Felons goods, Deodand Ho≈øpital, Furzes, Heath, Moor, Rent, Common, Hundred, Way, Ferry, Franchi≈øe, Seignory, Toll, Tallage, Picage, Pontage, Services, Portion of Tythes, Oblations, and the like. But a Fine levyed of Antient Deme≈øne Lands will not be good. Stat. 32 H. 8. Cap. 7. Coke 8. 145. We≈øt. Symb. 2. part

Anciently in levying a Fine of a Mannor, it wasBy what Names things may be levyed in Fines. Manerium. u≈øual to add to it, or explain it by the words, Deme≈øns, Rents, Seigniories, Courts, Pleas, &c. And ≈øuch Generals whereof it con≈øi≈øted, but this way is altered, and now it pa≈ø≈øeth by the name of Manerium cum pertinentiis. 3. In≈øt. 513.

That things pa≈ø≈øed in Fines mu≈øt be ≈øet down by their Nature, and quality, as Land, Meadow, Pa≈øture, &c. and by the place where they lye; there mu≈øt be apt words u≈øed to expre≈øs the thing named to pa≈øs by the Fine. For a Fine levyed de tenemento, or de hereditamento, or de duobus tenementis, for the uncertainty of the thing and unaptne≈øs of
the words, is void or voidable at lea≈øt for Error, Crooke 1. 196. Leon. Rep. 188. for the proper word to expre≈øs a Tenement or Hereditament in a Fine,Me≈ø≈øuagium. is Me≈øuagium, and a Fine levyed de uno me≈øuagio, or duobus me≈øuagiis is good.
That one Mannor may be parcel of another Mannor, and pa≈øs by the name of that Mannor. 20 A≈ø≈ø. pl. 54.

That a Ca≈øtle, Honour, or Hundred may be parcelCastellum ‚Ä¢ Honor-Hundredum. of a Mannor, and pa≈øs by the name of the Mannor whereof it is parcel. Or it may pa≈øs by its own proper name, as de Ca≈øtello de S. cum pertin. or de Hundredo de S. cum pertin. or de Honore de S. 20 A≈ø≈ø. pl. 54. 2 Edw. 3. 36. 1 Edw. 3. 4.

That the County, City, Town, Pari≈øh, Hamlet, and End≈øhip, wherein the things lye that are to pa≈øs by the Fine ought to be certainly named. And therefore if there be two Towns Walton and Street in the pari≈øh of Street, and a Fine is levyed of ≈øuch Lands in Street, in this ca≈øe Lands in Walton will not pa≈øs by this Fine, Walton being a di≈øtinct Town or Ville by it ≈øelf; and although Street the Pari≈øh comprehend both, yet in the Fine the lands in Walton ≈øhall not be ≈øaid to be comprized, unle≈øs Walton had been an Hamlet of Street, and that the Fine had been levyed of lands in the Pari≈øh of Street, then all would have pa≈ø≈øed well enough. Crooke 2. 120. Stock and Foxes Ca≈øe. So if a Mannor extend it ≈øelf into divers Towns, as into A. B. C. it is ≈øafe and be≈øt to expre≈øs all the Towns or none of them at all. For haply the Fine may be good, if the Mannor be onely named, and be not ≈øaid in what Town it doth lye; As de Manerio de S. cum pertin. but otherwi≈øe it mu≈øt be de Manerio de S. cum pertin. in A. B. & C. for if any one of the Towns be omitted, none of the Mannor in that Town ≈øo omitted will pa≈øs. 9 Edw. 4. 6.

That where divers Mannors be of one name, with di≈øtinction of North and South to it, as South S. North S. and the like, There it is ≈øafe to expre≈øs in the Original writ, and all the proceedings of the Fine, which of the Mannors is
intended to be pa≈ø≈øed by the Fine. And yet perhaps the Fine may be good to pa≈øs the Mannor intended to be pa≈ø≈øed without this di≈øtinction. Crooke 1. 196. 200. 9 Edw. 4. 6. Brooke Fines 44. 91. 12 H. 7. 6.

That when a Fine is but for the Pre≈øentationPre≈øentation, Par≈øonage, Vicaridg, Rectories, &c. to a Church onely it mu≈øt be de Advocatione Eccle≈øiae de S. and not cum pertin. And a Vicaridge endowed mu≈øt be de Advocatione Vicariae Eccle≈øiae de S. and not cum pertin. And where the Vicaridge is not endowed, it mu≈øt go under the≈øe words, de Advocatione Eccle≈øiae de S. And Par≈øonages, Rectories, Advow≈øons, Vicaridges, and Tythes impropriate pa≈øs not by the words de Advocatione Eccle≈øiae, but de Rectoria Eccle≈øiae de S. cum pertin. We≈øt. Symb. 2 part. Title Fines and Concords.

A Fine was levyed de Advocatione Eccle≈øiae de Advow≈øon and Rent re≈øerved. * Rectory and Rent re≈øerved. Wood. Hou≈øeboot, &c. Chappel or Ho≈øpital. Me≈øuage. C. ac de quat ‚Ä¢ or Librat. reddi ‚Ä¢ . cum pertin. in S. C. & B. Coke 3. 45.
A Fine was levyed of a Rectory out of which a Rent of 30 l. per Annum was rendred. Coke Lillingtons Ca≈øe.
High-wood, and Vnder-wood pa≈øs under the general denomination of Wood.
Hou≈øeboot, Hayboot, and Plowboot by the name of E≈øtovers.
A Chappel or Ho≈øpital will pa≈øs by the name of a Me≈øuage. 13 A≈ø≈ø. pl. 2.
So by the name of a Me≈øuage with the Appurtenances may pa≈øs an Hou≈øe, with a Shop, Curtilage, Garden, Orchard (and as ≈øome ≈øay, a Dovehou≈øe, and Mill) as parcel thereof.
That by the name of a Cottage, a Toft, Chamber,Cottage. and Celler will pa≈øs.

That part of an intire thing may pa≈øs by thePart of intire things. words, de medietate, de tertia parte, de quarta parte, &c. (as the Ca≈øe requires) or de duabus partibus in tres partes dividend. or de medietate omnium decimarum granorum, & feni ac terrae vocat. le Blackland ‚Ä¢
cum pertin. in H.

But if an intire thing, as a Mannor or Me≈øuage be parted, as if the Mannor of S. be divided into
two parts, and the divi≈øion be ≈øo made as that the Mannor for that part be not extinct, and a Fine is ‚Ä¢ be levyed of a part of it, it mu≈øt pa≈øs by the name ‚Ä¢ f the whole; As de Manerio de S. So if a Me≈øuage and 23 acres of land be parted, the part divided may pa≈øs by the name of one Me≈øuage and ten ‚Ä¢ ctes of land, and not de medietate ‚Ä¢ nius Me≈øuagii & viginti & trium acrarum terrae.

And Note that it is u≈øual in Fines to comprehend more number of acres then are intended to pa≈øs, yet in ≈øuch Ca≈øe no more ≈øhall pa≈øs, then what is intended and agreed upon between the Parties. Popham Rep. 105.

div.p:
AC de duobus Me≈øuagiis (or de uno Capitali Me≈øuagio) duobus Salinis, vocat. Witch-hou≈øes alias Salt-hou≈øes, duobus Shopis, duabus Cameris, ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ o Stabulo, ≈øex Cottagiis, uno Curtilagio, duobus Toft is, quatuor horreis, uno Molendino aquatico (or uno Molendino aquatico granatico) uno Molendino ventritico, or uno Molendino Fullonico, uno Columbar. decem Gardinis, decem Poma
‚Ä¢ iis, Centum acris terrae (or terrae aqua coopertae) riginti acris Prati, decem acris Pa≈øture, ≈øexdecim acris Bo≈øci (or Subbo≈øci, or de quatuor virgat. Bo≈øci) viginti acris Saliceti, viginti acris Jamp ‚Ä¢ orum & Bruere, viginti acris More, duabus acris Turbariae, octo acris Mo≈ø≈øet. ≈øex acris Juncar. decem acris Mari≈øci fri≈øci (or Mari≈øci ≈øal≈øi) duabus acris Alneti, quadraginta acris Arundin. decem acris Ru≈øcar. or de Rectoria Eccle≈øiae parochialis de C. ac de decimis Garbarum granorum & feni eidem Rectoriae ≈øpectan. or de decimis Garbarum ad Eccle≈øiam de C. qualiter cun
que ≈øpect. or de Rectoria impropriat. de R. cum pertin. or de Rectoria de K.
Or de Advocatione Eccle≈øiae de K. cum pertin, or de Advocatione Eccle≈øiae de K. or de Advocatione, Pre≈øentatione, Donatione, Libera di≈øpo≈øitione, & Jure Patronatus Eccle≈øiae de K.
Or de Rectoria de K. Ac de Advocatione Vicariae de K. or de Advocatione Eccle≈øiae de K. alternis vicibus cum acciderit.
Or de proficuis granorum, feni, Lane, & Agnorum, Ac de omnimodis aliis decimis cum pertin. in K.

Or de quadam portione decimarum aut pen≈øione in S. or de decimis garbarum granorum & feni cum pertin. in A. & B. Necnon de decimis Lane, Agnorum Oblationum, Obventionum & Emolumentorum, Ac de omnibus aliis decimis quibu≈øcunque provenien. cre≈øcen. ≈øeu renovan. in W. or de omnibus & omnimodis Oblation. decimis garbarum, granorum, feni, Lane, Lini porcellorum, ancarum, Agnellorum, &c. Et aliis Emolumentis quibu≈øcunque ≈øpectan. pertinen. cre≈øcen. ≈øive exi≈øten. cum pertin. in H.

Or de Communia pa≈øture pro omnibus & omnimodis Averiis, or de pa≈øtura pro tre≈øcentis ovibus cum pertin. in parochia de Dale, or de Communia pro omnibus Animalibus (or pro omnibus & omnimodis Animalibus) or pro decem ovibus, decem equis, vaccis, porcis, ≈øpadonibus, &c. or de Communia pa≈øturae quam praedictus A. habet & habere ≈øolebat pro omnibus Averiis ≈øuis in Centum acris pa≈øturae ip≈øius A. in S.

Or de libera Warrena ≈øua in D. or de una Wharfa, or de ≈øeperal. Pi≈øcaria in Aqua de S. or de liberis Pi≈øcariis in Aquis de B. C. & D. or de Pi≈øcaria, or de libertate unius Faldagii & cur≈øu ovium, or de libertate Faldagii, or de libertate Faldagii pro viginti ovibus, or de libero Faldagio ovium, or de libera Falda, or de Gurgite, or de Cur≈øu aquae currentis √† loco vocat. H. intra & per terras vocat. M.
Or de Nundinis de B. ≈øingulis Annis ad Fe≈øta de N. B. ibidem tenend. or de Mercat. de B. or de quieto & libero pa≈ø≈øagio ultra aquam de S. or de Chimino.

Or de viginti libra ‚Ä¢ . viginti ≈øolidat. decem de
‚Ä¢ r. uno Obulo & quadrant. Reddit. or de decem ‚Ä¢ arcat. reddit. or decem Marcis reddit. or de ‚Ä¢ eddit. unius libre piperis, unius Clavi Gariophil
‚Ä¢ , or unius Ro≈øe rubre, or unius quarter' hordei, ‚Ä¢ de reddit. Centum Gallinarum, or de duobus ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ch. Caponum, or de reddit. unius par Cheirodecarum, unius libre Cere, unius libre Cumini, ‚Ä¢ de reddit. Centum Gallorum, or de viginti ≈øo
‚Ä¢ dis annualis redditus exeun. de Manerio de D.

Or if it be of parts of things whereof the Fine is ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ be levyed, they mu≈øt be thus named, de Medieate Manerii de D. cum pertin. de tertia parte du
‚Ä¢ um me≈øuagiorum, or de duabus partibus in tres ‚Ä¢ rtes dividend. octo acrarum terrae, or de tertia parte tenementorum in C. in tribus partibus divi
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , or de Medietate decem Me≈øuagiorum, or de ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ rcia parte Rectoriae Eccle≈øiae de K. cum pertin
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ de Medietate omnium decimarum granorum, bladorum, garbarum & feni de terra vocat. F. cum pertin. in L. or de tercia parte Vic' Franc' pleg' cum pertin. bonorum & catallorum, waiviat, felon. fugitivorum, utlagat, in exigendo po≈øit. felon. de ≈øe, Deodand. & The≈øaur. invent. cum pertin. in D. or de tercia parte quinque librarum cum pertin. exeun. de Manerio de H.

And la≈øtly for your better in≈øtruction of placing the parcels in a Fine, ob≈øerve the≈øe following Rules, ‚Ä¢ s 1. That the worthy things mu≈øt be put fir≈øt, ≈øo a Me≈øuage mu≈øt be named before Land, a Mannor before a Me≈øuage, a Ca≈øtle before a Mannor, Arrable before Meadow, &c. Plowd. 168. 7 H. 6. 39. 2. Things general before ≈øpecial things; as land (being the genus, therefore) is to be placed before Meadow, Pa≈øture, Wood, Heath, Mari≈øh, &c. and Bo≈øcus mu≈øt precede Alnetum, Salicetum, &c. as wood is the genus to Wood-ground. 3. Intire things are to be ≈øet down before parts of things: de Manerio de. A. de Medietate Manerii de B. &c. 4. Parts of the things excepted mu≈øt follow the things them≈øelves out of which they are excepted. And if there be divers parcels in the Writ, that
thing out of which the exception is made mu≈øt be put la≈øt of all, thus, after all the re≈øt, de Manerio de B. cum pertin. in C. except. uno Me≈øuagio, duabus acris terrae & Advocatione Eccle≈øiae de B. &c. Regi≈øt. Orig. ≈øo. 6. 5. The thing excepted mu≈øt be certainly named, and in this there needs not the Addition of the words cum pertin. as are u≈øed after the things granted. 6. The Exception mu≈øt alwaies be of ≈øuch a thing as will lye in a Writ, and of ≈øuch a thing as is comprehended in the writ, as Precipe A. quod ju≈øte, &c. ten. B. Conventionem, &c. de uno Me≈øuagio, duabus acris terre, decem acris prati, & Centum acris pa≈øture cum pertin. except. una acra prati in L. Et e≈øt Concordia talis, ≈øcilicet, quod praedict. A. recogn. tenementa praedicta cum pertin. (except. preexcept.) e≈ø≈øe jus, &c. 7. Where the Original writ is of many things, if of eight things, as a Mannor, Hou≈øe, Rectory, &c. they are thus expre≈ø≈øed; fir≈øt, De uno Manerio: ≈øecondly, Ac de Rectoria: thirdly, Necnon de Me≈øuagio, &c. and for the fourth thing Aceciam: for the fifth, Praeterea: for the ≈øixth, Ac ulterius: for the ≈øeventh, Aceciam: and for the eight, Ac in≈øuper. And if there be more then to begin again.

div.head: CAP. VI. Ob≈øervations in Drawing the forms of Concords.
div.p:
TWo things are chiefly to be con≈øidered in the drawing of Concords of Fines. As fir≈øt, the Precipe, which is the Recital of the contents of the writ of Covenant and is called the Title or head of the Concord or Agreement, The form whereof is thus; Midd. ≈ø≈ø. Precipe A. B. quod ju≈øte, &c. teneat C. D. Conventionem, &c. de decem Me≈øuagiis, Centum acris terrae, & ≈øexaginta acris Pa≈øturae in I≈øllington, Et ni≈øi, &c. This Praecipe
is to expre≈øs the things in particular whereof the Fine is to be levyed, in the ≈øame order and words as they are mentioned in the Original writ, in which al≈øo the names of the parties, with their Additions mu≈øt be in≈øerted, as Precipe F. Comiti B. quod ju≈øte, &c. ten. H. F. Armigero, &c.

That therein the parcels mu≈øt be named according to the directions before ≈øet down in the fifth Chapter, which mu≈øt alwaies be according to the Rule in the Regi≈øter, comprehended in the en≈øuing ver≈øes:

q.p: Me≈ø.‚Ä¢gium, To≈øt.um, Mol.endinum, Col.nmbare, Gar.dinum, Terr.a,
Pra.tum, Pa≈ø.tu‚Ä¢a, Bo≈ø.cus, Brue.ra, Mora.
Junca.ria, Mari≈ø.cus, Alne.tum, Pi≈ø.caria, Red.ditus, Sectare priora.

div.p:
Secondly, The Concord it ≈øelf, as to which we are to ob≈øerve that the particulars (or parcels) ought not to be recited as fully in the Concord as when they were fir≈øt named in the writ of Covenant (or other original writ pertinent to a Fine) or as they are expre≈ø≈øed in the Precipe; but in≈øtead of naming of every particular over again it will be ≈øufficient to ≈øay thus, Et e≈øt Concordia talis ≈øcilicer quod praedictus A. recogn. tenementa praedicta cum pertin. e≈ø≈øe jus ip≈øius H. &c. where note that by the word tenementa any number or quantity of di≈øtinct things, or parcels, will be well enough and aptly expre≈ø≈øed, except the Precipe be of entire things by them≈øelves, as Precipe, &c. quod ten. Conventionem, &c. de Manerio, or Maneriis cum pertin. in A. here in this ca≈øe the Concord mu≈øt be, quod recogn. pred. Manerium, or pred. Maneria cum pertin. Neither will Me≈øuages named by them≈øelves in a Precipe pa≈øs by the word Tenementa in the Concord; So an Honour, Ca≈øtle, I≈øland, Barony, Hundred, Borough, Knights Fee, the Scite of a Mannor, a Park, a Prebendry, Rent, Common, a Warren, Fi≈øhing, Rectory, Tythes, Oblations,
Toll, Stallage, Pontage, View of Frank-pledge, a Liberty, Franchi≈øe, Office, Bayliwick, Fair, Market pa≈ø≈øage, the Moiety or part of any entire thing, Wreccum Maris, Advow≈øons of a Church, or portions of Tythes, mu≈øt be particularly named in the Concord, as well as in the Precipe, otherwi≈øe the Concord will not be good.

Although there be divers Cognizees in a Concord the right ≈øhall be limited to one of them, As where A. is Cognizor, B. and C. Cognizees, The Concord ≈øhall be quod praedictus A. recogn. praedicta tenementa cum pertin. e≈ø≈øe jus ip≈øius B. ut illa quae iidem B. & C. habent de dono praedicti A. & illa remi≈øit, & quiet. clam. de ≈øe, & heredibus ≈øuis prefat. B. & C. heredibus ip≈øius B. imperpetuum.

But where a Fine is from divers Cognizors, the Relea≈øe and Warranty mu≈øt be from all the Cognizors and their heirs, thus expre≈ø≈øed in the Concord where A. B. are Cognizors and C. Cognizee‚ñ™ ≈ø≈ø. quod predicti A. & B. recogn. predicta tenementa com pertin. e≈ø≈øe jus ip≈øius C. ut illa que idem C. habet de dono predictorum A. & B. & illa remi≈øit, & quier. clam. de ip≈øis A. & B. & heredibus ≈øuis pred. C. & hered. ≈øuis imperpetuum. Et predictus A. conce≈ø≈øit pro≈øe, & heredibus ip≈øius A. quod ip≈øi warant‚ñ™ prefat. C. & heredibus ≈øuis tenementa predicta cum pertin. contra predictos A. & heredes ≈øuos imperpetuum. And the like Waranty from B. But if the Fine be of Gavel-kind it is otherwi≈øe. Coke 5. 38.

It is u≈øual for divers per≈øons that have made ≈øeveral ≈ømall di≈øtinct purcha≈øes in one County to joyn together in one Fine (for ≈øaving charges:) And that the writ of Covenant be brought by all the Vendees again≈øt all the Vendors, and every one of them Warants for him≈øelf and his heirs, again≈øt him and them onely. We≈øt. Symb. 2. part.

div.head: CAP. VII. Before whom, and how, Fines are to be levyed; with the manner of drawing a Fine at Bar by the Serjeants at Law.
div.p: THe per≈øons before whom Fines are to be levyed are ≈øuch as either take Cognizance of Fines ex Officio, and by vertue of their Office, or ≈øuch as are appointed and authorized thereunto. Tho≈øe that do it ex Officio are the Lord Chief Iu≈øtice for the time being of the Court of the Common Pleas, who hath power to receive and certifie the Acknowledgment of all manner of Fines without any kind of Commi≈ø≈øion, as well in any place out of the Court, as in the Court. And ≈øo any two of the Iu≈øtices of the ≈øame Court may do it in open Court.
Tho≈øe that take Cognizance of Fines otherwi≈øe then ex Officio, are ≈øuch as do it by vertue of ≈øome Commi≈ø≈øion General or Special granted unto them by the King out of Chancery.

The fir≈øt ≈øort of tho≈øe that take and certifie Cognizances of Fines by vertue of Commi≈ø≈øion are Iu≈øtices of A≈ø≈øize, who, although they may do it by the general words of their Patent, yet they do not u≈øe to certifie them without a ≈øpecial writ of Dedimus pote≈øtatem.

Secondly, the Iudges of both Benches and Barons of the Exchequer, who do u≈øually fir≈øt take the Cognizance of Fines without Dedimus pote≈øtatem, and afterwards Certifie the ≈øame upon a Dedimus pote≈øtatem to warrant and ju≈øtifie their proceedings therein.

The third ≈øort are certain, di≈øcreet, hone≈øt, and under≈øtanding Gentlemen in the Country or place where the Cognizors which are to acknowledge the Fine re≈øide, who have alwaies a ≈øpecial writ of Dedimus pote≈øtatem directed unto them, whereby they
have power to do ≈øuch things therein, as the Chief Iu≈øtice doth daily ex Officio, upon ≈øurmi≈øe that the parties that are to acknowledge the Fine are not able to travel to We≈øtmin≈øter for the doing thereof. And by this Writ upon ≈øuch ≈øurmi≈øe power may be given to any Serjeant at Law, or to any Knight or Gentleman together to take the Cognizance of the per≈øons that are to be Cognizors in the Fine: And this they may take from them either altogether at once, or a≈øunder at ≈øeveral times, and in ≈øeveral places as they plea≈øe.

But herein great care mu≈øt be had by the Commi≈ø≈øioners in executing their Commi≈ø≈øion, lea≈øt they commit ≈øome notorious errour to make void the Fine. As if the Dedimus pote≈øtatem be to two Ioyntly to do it, and one of them doth it alone, or if the ≈øame be to three Ioyntly to do it, and two of the three onely do it, or the like, this will be Errour. So if one of the Cognizees be one of the Commi≈ø≈øioners, and he him≈øelf take the Cognizance of the Fine, this likewi≈øe will be Errour. F. N. B. 146, 147. Dyer 220. 11 H. 6. 21. Crooke 1. 249. Form. bene placitandi Tit. Erros A≈ø≈øignes.

The Iudges and Commi≈ø≈øioners impowered to take Cognizance of Fines, are to be careful of whom they take ≈øuch Cognizances for Fines before them: That they know the Cognizors, and ≈øo do not ≈øuffer one per≈øon to make Cognizance in the name of another, nor take any Cognizance from per≈øons prohibited by Law, and ≈øuch as are unfit to be Cognizors, as Infants, Mad men, Drunken men, and the like. And if husband and wife be Cognizors, the wife ought to be examined ≈øolely and ≈øecretly, whether ≈øhe be content of her own free will to part with her right in the land, or whether ≈øhe do it by the menace and threats, or out of fear of her Hu≈øband‚ñ™ and then the contents of the Fine mu≈øt be read di≈øtinctly to her; And if the Iudge doubt of her age, he may examine her upon oath, and ≈øo may Commi≈ø≈øioners, which being done, and the Fine read to the Cognizors they are to put their hands to the Concord. And then the Commi≈ø≈øioners are
to certifie the Cognizance of the parties the ≈øame day and year when it was taken, and ≈øo return the Dedimus, with the Concord, into the Court of Common Pleas, within a year after it is taken at farthe≈øt. And upon any of the Commi≈ø≈øioner's refu≈øal ≈øo to do, the party grieved may by Certiora ‚Ä¢ i compel him that hath it in his Cu≈øtody, his Executor, or Admini≈øtrator to certifie it.

div.head: How to ≈øue out a Fine before the Lord Chief Ju≈øtice of the Common Pleas.
div.p:
You are fir≈øt to draw your Precipe in paper, after this manner: ≈ø≈ø. Precipe T. S. Armigero & A. uxori ejus quod ju≈øte, &c. teneant. R. S. Armigero Conventionem, &c. de Maneriis de K. & S. cum pertinentiis ac de decem Me≈øuagiis, viginti Cottagiis, decem To≈øtis, & Centum acris Pa≈øture in M. Et ni≈øi, &c. which done ingro≈øs it fairly in Parchment with the Concord (according to the In≈øtructions, and Pre≈øidents in this Treati≈øe:) And then go with the Cognizor or Cognizors to the Lord Chief Iu≈øtice of the Common Pleas at his Chamber, and deliver your Parchment, if it requires ha≈øt, to the Clerk of the Fines who will cau≈øe the Caption to be writ underneath the Concord on the left hand (if it be not done before you come thither) thus, Capt. & cognit. primo die Maii, Anno regni domini no≈ø ‚Ä¢ ti Caroli ≈øecundi nunc Regis Anglie, &c. vice≈øimo, coram me, and al≈øo ≈øee that the Cognizors ≈øub≈øcribe their names to the Concord on the right hand, and inquire of him that comes with the parties to the acknowledgment of the Fine, if he knows them, and ≈øee that he ≈øub≈øcribes the Fine accordingly at the bottom, thus, A B. cogn. paries, which done he will get the Lord Chief Iu≈øtice his hand to the Caption of the Concord ingro≈ø≈øed in Parchment, And al≈øo to a Coppy thereof fairly written in paper which is to remain with the Cleck of the Fines: But the Concord in Parchment you are to carry to the Cur≈øitor of the County where the lands
lye, and there get your writ of Covenant made, which you are to carry before it be Sealed to the Alienation Office in the Temple, and there compound it; and get it entred, and indor≈øed: which done, you are to carry it back to the Cur≈øitor who will get it Sealed; and that being done, you are to make your Warant of Attorney for the Fine in this manner.
div.q: Bed. ≈ø≈ø. R. S. Armiger. Po. lo. ≈ø ‚Ä¢ o W. B. Attorn. ≈øuum ad pro≈øequend. breve de Con. ver≈øus T. S. & A. uxorem ejus de Maneriis, terris & tenementis in M. &c.
div.p: When you have made this Warrant of Attorny, you are to file it with the Clerk of the Warrants, who will ≈øign the Writ of Covenant with a Stamp for that purpo≈øe. Then file the writ of Covenant, and the Precipe and Concord together, and carry them to Mr. Jones his Office in the Middle-Temple, who returns the Writ of Covenant, and Signs the ≈øame with his Stamp; After this the Cu≈øtos Brevium is to have it to make his entry thereof upon the Roll, and indor≈øe upon the Writ when the Proclamations are to be made, from whom you mu≈øt carry it to the Clerk of the Kings Silver, who will perform what belongs unto it there; (And being once di≈øpatched that Office, it is then a Fine in force of Law) Afterwards carry it to the Chirographer who≈øe Office is in the Middle-Temple, and there the Clerk that deals for that County where the lands in your Fine do lye will make the Indentures of the Fine, and then it is fini≈øhed.

div.head: A Fine is acknowledged at the Bar after this manner.
div.p: Fir≈øt an Attorney mu≈øt deliver the Writ of Covenant Sealed, with the Precipe and Concord ingro≈ø≈øed in Parchment as above to one of the Serjeants at Bar, where the Cognizors are to be pre≈ø ‚Ä¢ nt.
Then the Serjeant mu≈øt de≈øire the Chief Iu≈øtice to record the appearance of the Cognizors which being granted by him, The Serjeant ≈øaith,
Then an≈øwereth the ≈øecond Prothonotary, or his Clerk,
Then the Sergeant ≈øhall an≈øwer thus,
Then the ≈øecond Prothonotary, or his Clerk, ≈øhall an≈øwer again, thus;

Then the Sergeant mu≈øt ≈øay, Ove vo≈øtre conge la paix e≈øt ti ‚Ä¢ l ≈øcilicet, &c. reciting in French the Concord ≈øo delivered unto him, as afore≈øaid by the Attorney, with relation to the particulars of the lands contained in the Precipe; And that being done, the Sergeant mu≈øt, if any one of the Cognizors be a Feme-covert, tell her that ≈øhe mu≈øt go up to the Pui≈øne Iudge to the Bench to be examined of her con≈øent, which Iudge taketh the Concord ≈øo written in Parchment, as afore≈øaid, and examineth her apart privately, and then delivereth it to the Prothonotary to be recorded.

Then take the Precipe and Concord, when the Court hath recorded it, and file it to the writ of Covenant, and paying the Fees of Court, pa≈øs it through the ≈øeveral Offices as you are before directed in the acknowledgment before the Lord Chief Iu≈øtice.

div.head: The manner of acknowledging and levying a Fine before Commi≈ø≈øioners.
div.p: Any Iudge of the Common Pleas, Kings Bench, or Baron of the Exchequer (as is before declared) may take the Caption of a Fine before the Dedimus pote≈øtatem be ≈øued out, which you may ≈øue out afterwards, and carry it under Seal to him that took the Cognizance of the Fine, and he will return the ≈øame.

A Fine may al≈øo be taken by ≈øpecial Commi≈ø≈øion in the Country; to do which, you mu≈øt deliver to the Cur≈øitor the Commi≈ø≈øioners names, one whereof mu≈øt be a Knight, by which with the Concord the Cur≈øitor will make the Dedimus pote≈øtatem, and get it ≈øealed for you.

Then deliver the Dedimus pote≈øtatem to the Commi≈ø≈øioners with the Precipe and Concord ingro≈ø≈øed in Parchment, with wax and ≈øeals unto it; and when the Cognizance is taken by them they mu≈øt return the Dedimus pote≈øtatem in this manner: Executio i≈øtius Commi≈ø≈øionis patet in quadam Schedula huic Commi≈ø≈øioni annex. And then file the Concord to the back of the Dedimus pote≈øtatem, and let the Commi≈ø≈øioners ≈øet their ≈øeals to the Concord, and their hands to the return of the Dedimus: The Caption of the Concord mu≈øt be thus,
div.q: Capt. & cognit. apud Villam B. in Com. B. decimo octavo die Augu≈øti, Anno Regni Domini no≈øtri Caroli Secundi nunc Regis Anglie, &c. vice≈øimo ≈øecundo coram nobis A. B. C. D. E. F.
div.p: Then when you have returned up your Dedimus pote≈øtatem, carry it to the Cur≈øitor, who will make you the writ of Covenant. And then pa≈øs the Fine as before is directed; onely in this ca≈øe if one of the Commi≈ø≈øioners that takes the Caption be not a Knight, you mu≈øt draw up a Certificate upon the back of the Concord, and carry it to a Iudge of the Common Pleas for his Allocatur.

div.head: The form of the Certificate is thus:
div.p: A B. gent. one of the Commi≈ø≈øioners in the Writ of Dedimus named, maketh Oath, that this Fine was duly executed, the Cognizees of full Age, and the Feme Covert (being ≈øecretly and apart examined) willingly con≈øented.

ARCANA CLERICALIA: OR A Treati≈øe OF Common Recoveries UPON WRITS of ENTRY IN le Po≈øt; WITH Notes and Ob≈øervations thereupon, AND A TABLE of Fees.
Printed Anno Dom. 1673.

div.head: Arcana Clericalia: OR A Treati≈øe OF Common Recoveries UPON Writs of Entry In le Po≈øt.
A Common Recovery defined.
div.p:
A Common Recovery is onely fictio Juris, or a Conveyance by con≈øent u≈øed for the better a≈ø≈øuring of Lands and Tenements upon any man, wherein the Recovery in value, the ≈øuppo≈øed Recompence for him which lo≈øeth his land, is but a fiction in Law. And this
Recovery by a≈ø≈øent is now by cu≈øtome become a Common A≈ø≈øurance and Conveyance, upon which V≈øes may be limitted and rai≈øed. Coke 1 part. Sir William Pelhams Ca≈øe 14. But there is a great difference between a Recovery by a≈ø≈øent, and a Recovery without a≈ø≈øent of the Parties. Vide 14. El. Cap. 8.

div.head: The former definition explained.
div.p:
IF any per≈øon have a de≈øire to render him≈øelf capable of di≈øpo≈øing of Lands or Tenements which are intayled upon him, and would be enabled to ≈øell, give, or bequeath them as he plea≈øeth, the cour≈øe is to procure ≈øome friend to bring a Writ again≈øt him for this Land; or in ca≈øe where he doth ≈øell the Land, perhaps he that buyeth it, or is to have it ≈øetled upon him, ≈øhall bring the Writ again≈øt him that is to make the A≈ø≈øurance of the Land, if it be with a ≈øingle Voucher. And in this ca≈øe the Demandant (being Plaintiff in this Action) doth ≈øuppo≈øe that the Tenant (or he again≈øt whom the Writ is brought) hath no right to the Land, but that he onely (viz. the Demandant) hath right thereunto, and that the Tenant came to the Land wrongfully by means of one Hugh Hunt a ≈øtranger therein named. And to this Writ the Tenant doth appear either by Attorney or in per≈øon, and then doth enter into defence of the Land: but in Pleading doth vouch to warant ≈øuch a man, from whom, or his Ance≈øtors, the Lands in que≈øtion are ≈øuppo≈øed to come to him or his Ance≈øtors, the Ance≈øtor of which third per≈øon obliging him≈øelf and his heirs by Conveyance, to warant and make good the Title to him or them to whom it was Conveyed: and thereupon he prayeth that this Vouchee (or third per≈øon) may be called into Court to defend this Title, whereupon being called he doth appear, and ≈øeem to defend the Title, denying that the Tenant came to the land wrongfully by means of the afore≈øaid Hugh Hunt, upon which he takes
I≈ø≈øue, or put him≈øelf upon the Country, whereupon the Demandant prayeth a further day to imparle or confer about the matter, which being granted unto him by the Court, at the day appointed the Vouchee, or third per≈øon afore≈øaid, by Agreement and con≈øent of the Parties comes no more into Court, but makes default, whereby judgment is given and awarded by the Court to the Demandant that he ≈øhall recover again≈øt the Tenant the Lands in que≈øtion, and that the Tenant ≈øhall recover over ≈øo much Land of the third per≈øon as is ≈øufficient to recompence him for the Land recovered from him, which the ≈øaid third per≈øon, or Common Vouchee, ought to have waranted and defended but ≈øuffered to be lo≈øt. And this is a Recovery in value or pro Rata. But if the Recovery be with a double Voucher, or treble Voucher, then the third per≈øon upon his appearance is to call or vouch to warant a fourth per≈øon (who mu≈øt be the Common Vouchee) and to alleadge in the ≈øame manner as the Tenant doth, and pray that ≈øuch fourth per≈øon may come in, who thereupon mu≈øt appear, and make default in ≈øuch manner as before is mentioned of the third per≈øon in the Recovery with ≈øingle Voucher. And ≈øo if there be more Vouchers. And then there mu≈øt be ≈øeveral Recoveries over in value again≈øt every one of them. But he that is la≈øt vouched or called to waranty is alwaies Common Vouchee, who is u≈øually Bag-bearer to the Cu≈øtos Brevium of the Court of Common Pleas, and hath not any Land to render in value upon the ≈øuppo≈øed warranty. And by this means grounded upon the ≈øtrict Principles of Law the fir≈øt Tenant doth willingly let go the land for the a≈ø≈øurance of the Purcha≈øor, and yet in truth hath no recompence over becau≈øe the Vouchee hath no Land to render in value.

div.head: Of what a Writ of Entry may be had, and by what Names.
div.p: A Precipe quod Reddat lyeth de Ca≈øtro, Manerio, Me≈øuagio, Tofto, Molendino, Columbari, Gardino, de Terra, Prato, Pa≈øtura, de Bo≈øco, de Jampnis & Bruera, de Mora, de Juncariis, de Mari≈øco ≈øal≈øo & fri≈øco, de libera Pi≈øcaria in Aqua de E. de redditu, de communia Pa≈øture pro omnibus averiis, de communia E≈øtoveriorum, de Pannagio pro Porcis, de Vi≈øu Francii Plegii, de Rectoria de L. cum pertin. de quibu≈ødam portionibus decimarum provenien. cre≈øcen. ≈øeu renovan. in K. de Advocatione Eccle≈øie de W. de Advocatione Vicarie Eccle≈øie de S.

It lyeth al≈øo, de Terra Aqua cooperta, de pa≈ø≈øagio ultra Aquam, de Balliva, de Officio, de quarta parte decimarum, de omnibus & omnimodis decimis, Majoribus, mixtis & minutis infra Villam ≈øive Hamlett. de B. infra Parochiam de A. quoquomodo cre≈øcen. contingen. ac annuatim renovan. &c. de Tofto & ≈øitu Molendini, de Hundredo de C. & de Ballivato de B. de Pa≈øtura ad ≈øex Boves, de roda Terre, de medietate unius rode Terre, de Shopa, de Wharfa, de Keia.

div.head: Of what things a Writ of Entry lyeth not.
div.p:
IT is ≈øaid in the Practical Coun≈øellor, fo. 196. that a Writ of Entry may not be de Pi≈øcaria, E≈øtoveriis, de Gardino; and in the Compleat Sollicitor printed this pre≈øent year 1672, fo. 62. that a Precipe quod Reddat. lyeth not de Pi≈øcaria de E≈øtoveriis, nec de communia Pa≈øture, nor of a Garden. And ≈øo it is ≈øaid in the Attorneys Guide, fo. 129 All which you will find to be otherwi≈øe by the Precedents of Recoveries in this Treati≈øe. And certainly it is a very great mi≈øtake for any per≈øon that treats publickly of Recoveries, to ≈øay that a Writ of Entry lyeth not of a Garden, the opinion being ≈øo directly
contrary to the Rule of the Regi≈øter, by which it evidently appears that the word Gardinum is alwaies u≈øed in real Actions, as Writs of Entry in le per cui & po≈øt de placito Terre, either for a Garden, or Orchard, as you will find by the en≈øuing Precedent.

Et predictus M. per A. L. Attorn. ≈øuum ven. & petir indicium de brevi predicto, Qua dicit quod breve illud vicio≈øum e≈øt in ≈øe & non impetrat. ver≈øus eundem M. ≈øecundum cur≈øum Regi≈øtri ≈øeu ≈øecundum formam & naturam brevis domine Regine de ingre≈ø≈øu ≈øuper di≈ø≈øei≈øinam in le per ≈øeu alicujus al. brevis domine Regine de placito Terre, quia in eodem brevi apparet quod predictus J. (inter alia) petit ver≈øus ip≈øum M. unum Pomarium modo & forma ≈øequen. videlicet Precipe M. T. Ar. quod ju≈øte, &c. reddat J. D. unum Me≈øuagium, unum Gardinum, unum Pomarium, &c. cum pertin. (inter alia) in G, &c. ubi ≈øecundum cur≈øum & formam Regi≈øtri hoc verbum Pomarium in aliquo brevi de placito Terre ≈øecundum naturam eju≈ødem brevis nunquam ponitur, quia hoc verbum Gardinum ≈øecundum cur≈øum & formam Regi≈øtri ≈øemper comprehendit in ≈øe Pomarium, undo ex quo, &c. New Book of Entries, intituled Formule bene placitandi, Title Abatement.

A Writ of Entry therefore cannot be brought de Pomario for the Rea≈øons above: nec de Fo≈ø≈øato, Stagno, nec de Advocatione, decimarum unius Curucat. Terre, nec de Homagio & fidelitat. nec de ≈øerviciis faciendis. nec de bovat. Mari≈øci, nec de Selione terre for the incertainty, becau≈øe a Selion, which is a land, containeth ≈øometimes an acre, ≈øometime half an acre, ≈øometimes more, and ≈øometimes le≈øs; it cannot be had of a Croft, nor of a yard land virgata Terre, nec de Fodina, de Minera, nec de Mercatu, for they lye not in deme≈øne but gain, nec de ≈øuperiori camera, 3 H. 6. fo. 1.

A Writ of Entry ought not to contain the ≈øame thing twice, as a Me≈øuage and an Hou≈øe parcel of the ≈øame Me≈øuage. 3 Ed. 4. fo. 28. 46 Ed. 3. fo. 26.
nor to name a Town, and a Hamlet within the ≈øame Town, 22 Ed. 3. fo. 11. 41 Ed. 3. fo. 22. but the Practice is otherwi≈øe at this day.

div.head: Ob≈øervanda.
div.p: In every Recovery four things are principally to be regarded, viz.
Fir≈øt, The Demandant who is Plaintiff in the Writ of Entry, and may be called the Recoverer.
Secondly, The Tenant of the Land who is Defendant to the Writ of Entry, and in regard the Land is recovered again≈øt him, he may not improperly be termed the Rocoveree.
Thirdly, The Vouchee being that per≈øon who is vouched by the Tenant, or he whom the Tenant calleth to warranty for the Lands demanded in the Count.

La≈øtly, The Land it ≈øelf which is to be recovered, being the ≈øubject matter of a Recovery, which you mu≈øt be very careful and exact to place Regularly according to the cour≈øe u≈øed by the Cur≈ø ‚Ä¢ tors, and the directions above given.

In a Recovery with double Voucher, you mu≈øt either by a Fine ≈øur Cognizance de droit come ceo, &c. or by a Deed of Feoffment, or Bargain and Sale inrolled, or Lea≈øe and Relea≈øe make him (you intend to be) Tenant at the time of the Writ of Entry brought: For every Writ of Entry mu≈øt alwaies be brought again≈øt him that mu≈øt be a perfect Tenant of the Freehold of the Land demanded at the return of the Writ: Becau≈øe the E≈øtate of the Tenant in Tayl (which is the Vouchee) is barred in re≈øpect of the A≈ø≈øe ‚Ä¢ z onely which are or may be recovered in value, and of Execution ≈øued by the Tenant again≈øt him.

If Tenant to a Recovery have but an E≈øtate for life, or be Tenant in Dower or by the Courte≈ø≈øe of England, it is requi≈øite for the ≈øtrengthning of his Recovery that he make a Conditional The form of which Surrender ≈øee at the end of this Treati≈øe. Surrender of his E≈øtate to him in the Rever≈øion or Remainder, to the end he may be a pre≈øent Tenant of the Inheritance, and then to bring the Writ of Entry again≈øt him, and after that the Recovery is executed, the particular Tenant for breach of the Condition may enter and enjoy his term notwith≈øtanding ≈øuch Surrender.

div.p: Although this is called a Recovery with ≈øingleWhat a Recovery with ≈øingle Voucher is. Voucher, yet you will find two Recoveries included therein, The fir≈øt by the Demandant again≈øt the Tenant which in the form next above is thus, Ideo con≈øideratum e≈øt quod predicti Carolus & Johannes (which are the Demandants) recuperent ≈øei≈øinam ≈øuam ver≈øus prefatum Galfridum (the Tenant) de tenementis predictis cum pertin. And the ≈øecond Recovery is by the Tenant again≈øt the Common Vouchee, in the≈øe words in the precedent next above, Et quod idem Galfridus habeat de terra predicti Edmundi (the Common Vouchee) ad valentiam, &c.

div.head: Ob≈øervanda.
div.p: In a double Voucher, three Recoveries are mentioned,What is meant by a Recovery with double Voucher. that is to ≈øay, one where the Demandant hath judgment to recover the land again≈øt the Tenant, another where the Tenant hath likewi≈øe Iudgment to recover in value again≈øt the Voucher, and la≈øtly, where the fir≈øt Voucher hath al≈øo the like Iudgment to recover in value again≈øt the (≈øecond or common) Vouchee.

Now the intent and ≈øcope of a Common RecoveryThe intent and ≈øcope of a Recovery with double Voucher. with double Voucher is to bar the fir≈øt Voucher and his Heirs of every ≈øuch E≈øtate as at any time was in the ≈øame Voucher, or any of his Ance≈øtors who≈øe Heir he is of ≈øuch E≈øtate, and all other per≈øons of ≈øuch right to a Rever≈øion or Remainder as was thereupon at any time expectant or dependant, and of all Lea≈øes, Charges, and Incumbrances derived out of any ≈øuch Revertion, or Remainder, and that will be al≈øo a perpetual bar of ≈øuch E≈øtate, whereof the Tenant was then ≈øeized in Rever≈øion or Remainder, expectant or dependant upon the ≈øame.

If the Vrit of Entry be retornable ≈øo late inRecovery indor≈øed upon the Label. the Term, that the Writ of Sei≈øin cannot come in, retornable the ≈øame Term, but that it mu≈øt be retornable the next Term, Then ob≈øerve after the retorn of the Writ of Sei≈øin in the Exemplification to break off, and conclude with Quae omnia & ≈øingula, &c. And indor≈øe upon the Label, Ad quem diem hic ven. predictus (petens) in propria per≈øona ≈øua Et Vic. videlicet A. B. B. de uno Me≈øuagio, &c. per breve no≈øtrum de Ingre≈ø≈øu ≈øuper di≈ø≈øei≈øinam in le Post: Ideo tibi precipimus quod prefat.
