div.head: The Form of a Surrender or Lea≈øe to make a Tenant to the Precipe.
div.p: THis Indenture made, &c. Between A. B. of, &c. of the one part, and C. D. of, &c. of the other part, Witne≈ø≈øeth that whereas the ≈øaid A. B. doth hold for the term of his life, One Me≈øuage, &c. in D. in the County of E. the immediate Rever≈øion or Remainder whereof doth belong to the ≈øaid C. D. and his Heirs, or to the Heirs of his body, lawfully begotten, for ever: Now the ≈øaid A. B. for the perfecting of ≈øome A≈ø≈øurance ≈øhortly to be made of the ≈øame Me≈øuage, &c. by way of Common Recovery hath granted and ≈øurrendred, and by the≈øe pre≈øents doth grant and ≈øurrender unto the ≈øaid C. D. and his Heirs, upon the Condition herein after-mentioned, All that the ≈øaid Me≈øuage, &c. And all the E≈øtate, Right, Title and Intere≈øt of him the ≈øaid A. B. therein, To have and to hold to him the ≈øaid C. D. and his Heirs upon Condition That if the ≈øaid C. D. do not pay, or cau≈øe to be paid unto the ≈øaid A. B. the ≈øum of One Thou≈øand pounds of lawful mony of England, upon the fir≈øt day of, &c. next en≈øuing the Date hereof, That then and from thenceforth this pre≈øent Grant and Surrender ≈øhall be utterly void and of none effect, and that then al≈øo it ≈øhall and may be lawful to and for the ≈øaid A. B. into the ≈øaid Me≈øuage, &c. to re-enter and the ≈øame to have again, re-po≈ø≈øe≈øs and enjoy, as in his former E≈øtate and Right, any thing in the≈øe pre≈øents contained to the contrary in any wi≈øe notwith≈øtanding. In Witne≈øs, &c.

div.head: The Form of Drawing a Recovery at the Bar, by the Sergeants at Law.
div.p: ONe of the Sergeants retained for this purpo≈øe mu≈øt ≈øpeak to the Chief Iu≈øtice upon the Bench, and ≈øay demaundes, and ≈øhew the Tenant.
After leave given by the Court the Sergeant counts by the Prothonotaries Remembrance, according as the Writ is there entred in this manner, by the fir≈øt Sergeant, viz.

Ceo vous mon≈øtre Jean at Oakes, que Jean at1 Sergeant. Style a tort luy de≈øorce de l'Mannor de Sale ove≈øque les appurtenances en le Countie de M. (and ≈øo recite all the Lands as they are expre≈ø≈øed in the Prothonotaries Remembrance delivered unto him) Et pur ceo a Tort entan ‚Ä¢ que e≈øt ≈øon droit & ≈øon inheritance d'ount il me≈øm' fuit ≈øei≈øie en ≈øon deme≈øne come de Fee & droit en temps la peace en temps la Raigne no≈øtre Seigniour le Roy que ore e≈øt, & les e≈øplees ont pri≈øt Come en faucher de blees amountant al value de demie Mark & plus, & en quel le dit Jean at Style n'ad pas entre ≈øi non puis di≈ø≈øei≈øin quel Hugh Hunt de ceo torciou≈øment & ≈øans judgment ad fait al dit J. O. deins 30 ans darrein pa≈ø≈øe, Et ≈øi le dit J. S. ceo voile dedire vous aves cy le dit J. O. que ont ad port ≈øon Suit bon.
Then the Sergeant of the Tenant mu≈øt ≈øay chus;
Vous aves cy le dit J. S. que defend le tort &2 Sergeant. force & vouch a garanty A. B. Et prie que il ≈øoit ≈ø „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ on deins le Countie avant dit per le aid de ce≈øt Court.

Then the Sergeant of the Vouchee mu≈øt de≈øire3. Sergeant. the Iudges to Record the appearance of the Vouchee (if it be with a double Voucher, and ≈øo of every Vouchee, unle≈øs it be the Common Vouchee) which done, he mu≈øt ≈øay, Vous aves cy le dit A. B. que cy e≈øt pri≈øt d'entre en la Garantie, & prie que le demandant counteroit envers luy.
Then the fir≈øt Sergeant mu≈øt ≈øay, Autiel Count 1 Sergeant. mutatis mutandis.
Then the Sergeant of the Vouchee (being the3. Sergeant. third Sergeant) mu≈øt ≈øay thus;
Autiel defence mutatis mutandis, vous avez cy le dit A. B. que vouch a Garanty Edmund Clent, Et prie que il ≈øoit ≈øummon en la Countie avant dit per le aid de ce≈øt Court.
Then the fourth Sergeant mu≈øt ≈øay, Vous avez4. Sergeant. cy le dit Edmund Clent que cy e≈øt pri≈øt d'entre en la Garanty, Et prie que lei demandant Counteroit envers luy.
Autiel Count mutatis mutandis.1 Se ‚Ä¢ g.

Autiel defence mutatis mutandis, vous avez cy4 Sergeant. le dit Edmund Clent que le dit Hugh Hunt ne di≈ø≈øei≈øe pas le dit J. O. ≈øi come le demandant per ≈øon briefe & Count ≈øuppo≈øe, Et ≈øur ceo luy mitta ≈øur la pais.
Ove vo≈øtre conge nous voilumus imparle.1 Sergeant.

NB. The Demandant u≈øeth not to come to the Bar, but onely he that is Tenant to the Precipe quod reddat, and the Vouchees in per≈øon (unle≈øs by Warrant of Attorney as before) There mu≈øt be one Sergeant for the Demandant, one for the Tenant, and a ≈øeveral Sergeant for every ≈øeveral Vouchee.

div.head: DIRECTIONS For Sueing out RECOVERIES Together with the U≈øual FEES Incident thereunto.
div.p: DRaw your PRECIPE in Pape ‚Ä¢ in the ≈øame manner as you are directed in the beginning of this Treati≈øe, which being drawn you mu≈øt carry it to the Cur≈øitor of that County wherein the Lands lye, who will thereby make you a Writ of Entry ≈øur di≈ø≈øei≈øin in le Po≈øt. When your Writ of Entry is made, you mu≈øt carry it to the Alienation Office (now in the Inner Temple) and their compound it with one of the Commi≈ø≈øioners, then pay the Fine to the Receiver, who there attends to take it, and then you mu≈øt get the Writ of Entry entred into the Commi≈ø≈øioners Book, and there Indor≈øed with Mr. Crew's (the Doctors) hand, with the hands of two of the Commi≈ø≈øioners unto it. Then carry it back to the Cur≈øitor to be Sealed, from whence you mu≈øt carry it to the Kings Attorney General for his hand.

Then, in ca≈øe the Tenant in your Writ of Entry does appear in per≈øon ≈øo that your Recovery may be taken at the Bar, you mu≈øt ingro≈øs your Precipe in a large hand in that Prothonotaries Office in which you enter according to this form.
Midd. ≈ø≈ø. PR. Willielmo Herne quod ju≈øte, &c. reddat Johanni Adams gen. unum Me≈øuagium & decem acras Pa≈øture Tenens in propria per≈øona vocat Edm. Clent. cum pertin. in Enfield. que clam. &c.

In this manner you are to enter a Precipe for a ≈øingle Voucher upon the Remembrance, but if it be for a double or treble Voucher it mu≈øt be ≈øtill the ≈øame except in the Margin of the Precipe: If it be for a double Voucher you mu≈øt ≈øay, Tenens in propr. per≈øona vocat Henr. How≈øe qui pre≈øens vocat Edmundum Clent. And if it be with a treble Voucher ≈øay thus, Tenens in propria per≈øona voc. Henr. How≈øe, qui pre≈øens voc. Thomam Greene, qui pre≈øens vocat Edmundum Clent.

Then when you are ready to have your Recovery taken at the Bar, having your Tenant and Vouchees ready, the Court being at lei≈øure deliver the Remembrance, on which your Precipe is entred to one of the Sergeants at the Bar, who with two more of his brethren, if it be a ≈øingle Voucher; three more if it be a double Voucher; or four Sergeants more if it be with a treble Voucher will ≈øoon di≈øpatch you: which being done carry back the Remembrance to the Prothonotary ≈øitting in Court who will mark it, Ad Barram, in the Margent of the Precipe, and pay the Fees in Court. All which being done, then draw your Recovery, enter it upon a Plea Roll, which the Prothonotary will give you for that purpo≈øe; Then make an Exemplification thereof for your Clyent, then make your Writ of Sei≈øin, and return the ≈øame together with your Writ of Entry according to your Precedents in ≈øuch ca≈øes; Then examine your Recovery with the Prothonotary (having fir≈øt perfected the Precipe
in the Remembrance according to the Te≈øte and Retorn of your Writ of Entry) then docket your Recovery, which done the Prothonotary will ≈øign your Exemplification and Writ of Sei≈øin, both which you mu≈øt get Sealed; Then carry your Writs of Entry and Seizin to the Inrollment Office in the Temple to be Inrolled, and la≈øtly file your Writs of Entry and Seizin, with the Cu≈øtos brevium of the Common Pleas, who al≈øo keeps his Office in the Temple.
Note, You may pa≈øs your Recovery at the Bar before you ≈øue out your Writ of Entry for the better di≈øpatch of your Clyent, and ≈øo is the Common u≈øe.
Note, If your Clyent be a Nobleman, you mu≈øt place him in the middle of the Bar, between the Kings Sergeants or the two other elde≈øt Sergeants in their ab≈øence.
Note, The Demandant in any‚ñ™ Recovery need not appear at the Bar.

But if your Recovery be with a ≈øingle Voucher, and the Tenant to the Precipe do not appear at the Bar, in ≈øuch ca≈øe you may ≈øue out a Dedimus Pote≈øtatem from the Cur≈øitor directed to Commi≈ø≈øioners to take the Caption, having ready Iugro≈ø≈øed your Precipe quod reddat, and Warrant of Attorney, as your Precedent directs; then having your Dedimus Pote≈øtatem executed and returned from the Commi≈ø≈øioners, carry the Caption back again to the Cur≈øitor, who will make you a Mittimus and Tran≈øcript of all your proceedings, which you mu≈øt enter in a ≈ømall hand upon a Plea-Roll (taken from the Prothonotary) beginning with the Mittimus which is the lea≈øt of the two Writs, and filed backwards; which having Recorded verbatim and litteratim; then in one continued Line begin and go on with the annexed Writ of Dedimus, and do the like to the end; and then about a thumbs breadth
di≈øtance, begin underneath and make an entry of your Recovery in great hand on the ≈øame Roll.

But if your Recovery be with a double Voucher (which is mo≈øt u≈øual) and the Tenant to the Precipe do not appear at the Bar, then your proceedings are as followeth: You mu≈øt ≈øue out a Writ of Summons again≈øt the Tenant, together with a Dedimus Pote≈øtatem, as before directed; and at the fifth Return, inclu≈øive from the Writ of Entry, accounting that of the Writ of Entry for one, the Writ of Summons returned, together with a Tran≈øcript of the Entry of the Summons being fairly Ingro≈ø≈øed, and a Tran≈øcript of the Caption, being (as before) made by the Cur≈øitor, being all fixed together you may ≈øo pa≈øs it at the Bar. And in ca≈øe the Vouchee do not appear at the Bar at the Return of the Summons; then you are to make out another Writ of Summons again≈øt the Vouchee, and to proceed as before; and having all your Writs and Tran≈øcripts fixed together, you are to deliver it to a Sergeant to be pa≈øt at Bar.
But if your Tenant do appear at Bar, then you mu≈øt have a Writ of Summons again≈øt the Vouchee, and ≈øo again≈øt every Vouchee, if it be with more Vouchers, and proceed therein as before directed.
Note, You mu≈øt make due Entries upon Record of all your proceedings as they go on.
Note, That Captions may be taken before a Iudge of A≈ø≈øize, and Certified without a Dedimus.

Note, You having Ingro≈ø≈øed your Summons in Parchment, may examine it by the Roll with the Prothonotary: In like manner you may pa≈øs it at Bar, by the return of the Caption, before you have a Tran≈øcript thereof from the Cur≈øitor, as well as afterwards.
Note, You mu≈øt carefully file all your Warrants of Attorney with the Clerk of the Warrants, and all your Writs what≈øoever with the Cu≈øtos brevium.

Note, If your Clyent will be at the Charge, you By the Stat. 23. El. Cap. 3. an Office was erected for the Inrollment of Writs of Entry and Sei≈øin, and Writs of Covenant; and it is thereby Enacted that the Exemplifications of ≈øuch Writs ≈øhall have the ≈øame force and power as the Writs them≈øelves. may have both the Writs of Entry and Seizin exemplified with their Returns, for fear of any mi≈øcarriage in filing them, which Exemplifications are u≈øually had at the Inrollment Office, now kept by Mr. Sergeant in Brick-Court in the Middle Temple.

Note, The mo≈øt proper way to find out a Recovery formerly pa≈øt is to ≈øearch with the Clark of the Warrants, who u≈øeth to take Notes out of all the Plea Rolls of all the Prothonotaries Offices, and enters them all di≈øtinctly and fairly into a Regi≈øter-book, every Office by it ≈øelf, and al≈øo the number Roll.
